dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT IN ALICE'S ROOM. A little bit of moonlight coming i through the tiny window might make a highlight here and t but that's about all. Words begin to crawl across the scr WRITTEN WORDS (crawl) Of good family, albeit one of modest means, she was a comely young woman and not without prospects. Therefore it was at once heartbreaking and astonishing to her mother that she would enter into marriage with William Munny, a known thief and murderer, a man of notoriously vicious and intemperate disposition. We can HEAR STRAWBERRY ALICE and DAVEY BUNTING breathing heavily and the bed creaking.

dialogues.speaker: WRITTEN WORDS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were married in St. Louis in 1870 and they traveled North to Kansas where he engaged in farming and swine husbandry. Davey and Alice are picking up speed now, breathing faste and even snorting a little, and it's cold as Jesus in Neb in the winter so when the blanket slips, Alice snarls and gasps.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The blanket, for chrissake, cowboy, the blanket. There are six of these little rooms... one for each whore behind Greely's Beer Garden and Billiards and the walls a just boards so you can hear what's happening in the other rooms and right now, from DELILAH'S room, you can hear a high-pitched, merry little giggle and that's important. WRITTEN WORDS (crawl contd.) She bore him two children in the eight years of their marriage and when she died, it was not at his hands as her mother might have expected, but of smallpox. That was in 1878.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, please.... No, no goddamn you. Alice and Davey have stopped fucking and started listenin but they don't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Crawl cont'd) It wasn't until 1881... three yeats later... that a cowboy named Mike cut up a whore in Big Whiskey, Nebraska in the Niobrara River country. (end crawl) MIKE'S VOICE 0.S. Davey, come a runnin' lad an' hold the thieving cunt... A blur of action as Davey leaps from the bed and dashes o of the room naked...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...brand you like a damn steer, bitch... and Alice is right behind him, wrapping herself in a blanket as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DELILAH is backed up against the wall, her face bleeding, and she is throwing the contents of her chamber pot on MI who is advancing on her with an open barlow knife and Dav busts into the room naked and Alice follows him and peopl are shouting in other rooms.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (wiping shit off himself ) Hold the bitch, Davey, hold her. The one coal oil lamp in the room gives off just enough l that you can make all this out. Certainly you can see tha Mike, who is wearing leggings and no shirt, is a big toug man, unshaven, eyes inflamed with whiskey...

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: HOLD HER, DAMMIT, DAVEY! If you don't hold her I'll cut her tits off. LITTLE SUE, a fifteen year old whore, is in the doorway, eyes wide with terror and Alice screams at her.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Get Skinny, for God's sake! SKINNY! Davey is reluctant about the whole thing but he is afraid Mike and he gets behind Delilah and grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Wh-what you gonna do, Mike?  3. Mike is doing it now and Delilah is screaming while he ca her face with the barlow knife and blood is all over, splashing on Davey and Davey, who is just a kid, after al nineteen with a big shock of unruly red hair and innocent blue eyes, is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Thieving cunt, I'll...

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Mike, don't, Jesus, don't...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: SKINNY! Bring your gun. Alice can't wait for Skinny and she jumps on Mike's back brings the big man down and she fights him though she's n a big woman. Alice is twenty-five but she's been around some, whored some tough cow-towns, and she has too much b and character in her face to be outright pretty but she attracts men like flies. Sure she has some smallpox scars on her face, but they're common and there are only a few them, not like on Skinny whose mean little face is eaten right up with them.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON SKINNY DUBOIS
dialogues.text: STANDING THERE IN THE DOORWAY, his nasty face eaten with smallpox scars and he is looking at Delilah who is a foun of blood, looking at her coldly, and looking down at the melee on the floor and, pointing the big Navy Colt in his hand, he says,

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Get offa her, asshole. And he says it so cold and with such authority that every goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SNOW/MOONLIGHT/THE SHADOWY BUILDINGS and the silence of t Nebraska winter except for the sound of the snowshoes. The snow has obliterated the Main Street of Big Whiskey g the impression that the dark, low buildings are scattered random. The only structure with any sign of life is Greel Beer Garden and Billiards which shows a glowing window an two horses out front and that is a hundred yards away fro the struggling silhouettes of the two men on snowshoes. T big one is LITTLE BILL DAGGETT and he is very big, wrappe in a huge bearskin robe. The smaller one is CLYDE LEDBETTER who isn't small though has only one arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...wouldn't let you settle it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Hell, you know how Skinny is. Says he's gonna shoot 'em...an I says, "Skinny, you can't do that," an' he says, "Well, then get Little Bill down here an' let's settle this" an' I says, "Bill's sleepin', Skinny," an'... They make their way in silence through the snow, getting close now, close to Greely's and the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DELILAH ON HER BED, her face covered with blood-soaked ra except for her eyes. Alice has hot water and is ministeri to her and Little Bill is looking down at her from his enormous height, still in his bearskin. He looks disguste

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: She ain't gonna die, huh? You can now see fear in Delilah's eyes, and the other who ...CROW CREEK KATE with crazy pop-eyes and frizzy hair, a LITTLE SUE who is fifteen and meek even when she isn't terrified, and FAITH who is the oldest of them and not ve attractive and SILKY who is blonde and the prettiest... a watching from vantage points in the doorway or in the roo

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (determined) She's gonna live. ittle Bi urns to Little Bill t t go) She didn't steal nothin', She didn't touch his poke.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (stopping and turning) No?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: All she done was... when she seen he had a teensy little pecker... she gave a giggle. That's all. She didn't know no better. Little Bill turns away, disgusted, and starts out of the room and Alice gets up and follows him.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gonna hang 'em, Little Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey sitting naked on the floor of the bar room and Mike sitting near him, still in his leggings and both men are shivering because they are fifteen feet from the potbelli stove where Clyde is standing watching them. It is a big room, with a crude bar and four tables and so moose and elk heads on the wall. The door near the rear where it says "Billiard Room" leads not to a Billiard Roo but to the six little "rooms" that are the whorehouse and and now you can hear Delilah groaning from there. And Little Bill enters from the back of the bar room, sto to pass through the doorway under the sign that says "Bil Room." Little Bill is huge and ominous. Some say he acquired the bearskin by staring the bear to death and others say he drowned the animal in spit. Anyhow, he's big with a droop moustache and he is sucking on his church warden's clay p and you know he isn't scared of anything. And the two cowboys are scared to death, not just shiveri from the cold, and Bill just looks down at them and sucks his pipe and Alice comes in from the back way too and the Skinny and a couple of the whores gather in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Clyde, step across to the German's an' fetch up one of his bullwhips. Stark terror on the faces of Davey and Mike as Clyde exit

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: A whippin'? That's all they get? After what they done?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (sucking on his pipe) Whippin' ain't a little thing, Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: But what they done, they...

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (he has a piece of paper in his hand) Shut up, Alice. Little Bill, a whippin' ain't gonna settle this.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing the paper) This here's a lawful contract... betwixt me an' Delilah Fitzgerald, the cut-whore. Now I brung her clear from Boston, paid her expenses an' all, an' I got a contract which represents an investment of capital.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (sympathetic to the argument ) Property.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Damaged property. Like if I was to hamstring one of their cow ponies.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: You figure nobody'1ll want to fuck her.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Hell no. Leastways, they won't pay to do it. Alice is listening to this and her eyes are like coals an you can hear Delilah moaning in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She could maybe clean up around the place or somethin', but nobody's gonna pay good money for a cut-up whore.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (making up his mind and turning to the shivering cowboys) You boys are off of the Spade Outfit. Got your own string of ponies?

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (nodding) I... I got f-f-f-four.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (sullenly) Six. Skinny nods, pleased, and Alice watches, her eyes still h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess you boys just as soon not have no trial an' fuss, huh? Davey and Mike nod, willing to say anything Little Bill w

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL CONT'D
dialogues.text: (to Mike) Alright. You done the cuttin’... Come the thaw, you bring in five of them ponies an' give 'em over to Skinny here.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Five!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (to Davey) An' you... you give over two ponies, hear? - Clyde bangs in out of the snow with a buggy whip in his h

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I couldn't find no bullwhips, Bill. The German...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Don't matter, we don't need no whips. (to Mike and Davey) Spring comes an' Skinny don't have them ponies, I'm gonna...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You... you ain't even gonna... whip "em?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: I fined 'em instead.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: For what they done? Skinny gets some ponies an' that's... ?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (approaching her) Ain't you seen enough blood for one night? Hell, Alice, they ain't loafers nor tramps nor bad men. They're hard workin' boys that was foolish. Why if they was given over to wickedness in a regular way...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (furious) Like whores?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice, tend to Delilah. For a long moment Alice just stands there glaring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAYLIGHT AND A BASIN OF BLOODY WATER and Little Sue is ju dipping another towel in the hot water next to Delilah's bed, changing the bandages. All the whores are there in various states of dress, lounging on the floor, leaning against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: SILKY
dialogues.text: (to Alice) If Delilah don't care one way or the other, what're you so riled about?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (passionately) Just because them smelly assholes like to ride us like horses don't mean we got to let 'em brand us like we're horses. Maybe we ain't nothin' but whores, but by God we ain't horses. Silky is thinking it over, frowning, and then she makes h decision.

dialogues.speaker: SILKY
dialogues.text: (to Alice) I got a hundred an' twelve dollars. That's everythin'.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What about you, Faith?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Two hundred... (there are gasps) Two hundred an' forty.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Jesus, Faith, what you been doin', givin' Skinny somethin' special? All the women laugh and Delilah through her bandages make gurgling sound and Little Sue's eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: (indicating Delilah) She laughed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what Kate got, Silky got some, an' mine, an' Little S...

dialogues.speaker: SILKY
dialogues.text: (soberly) It ain't enough.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (determined) Not yet maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hog in the mud, snorting and squealing, ugly as hell BILL MUNNY in the mud with him, pushing and shoving, tryi to move the stubborn animal and Munny goes down face firs and comes up more covered with mud than he already was an the words on the screen say, WRITTEN WORDS (super) Some months later, Hodgeman County, Kansas. Munny is thirty-five or forty years old, his hair is thin and his moustache droops glumly over his stubbled jaw. If it were not for his eyes he would look like any pig farme with his canvas overalls tucked in his boots pushing on a hog. He is pushing on the hog again, grunting with the effort, when he hears the voice.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don't look like no rootin', tootin', sonofabitchin', cold-blooded assassin.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (looking up, startled) Huh? THE KID is only six feet away, the sun behind him, sittin on a very big and very ancient Morgan horse. He's wearing wide-brimmed Texas hat, a vest, a holstered pistol, and h is a wiry kid, maybe twenty years old, with scraggly blon hair, four of his upper front teeth missing, and a funny, squinty way of looking out of his watery blue eyes. Most all, he doesn't look very prosperous.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I seen how you got only three fingers on your left hand, though, so I guess you're calling yourself Mister Bill Munny. Munny does indeed have three fingers on his left hand and doesn't like this conversation at all.  10.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: William Munny, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Same one as shot Charlie Pepper in Lake County?

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Paw! Hey, Paw! The voice belongs to WILL, a skinny ten-year-old who dash up with his seven-year-old sister, PENNY, right on his he The kids are ragged and dirty, they don't look well fed o even very healthy. Even as Will speaks to his father, Mun his eyes, and Penny's too, go to The Kid. They don't see many strangers.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: What is it, son?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Two more hogs got the fever. Munny winces. The Kid ignores the interruption.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You shot Charlie Pepper, didn't you? And you're the one killed william Harbey an' robbed the train over...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (sharply) Hold on, mister. (to Will) Son, this here pig gotta be moved outta this pen, away from them others. Penny, you give yer brother a hand...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: (emotional) This one's sick too? Munny ignores the question, already on his way to the miserable-looking shack.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Let's talk inside, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny selects a tin cup from a wash pan of dirty dishes. is dark and cool inside his one room sod hut... and poor. The Kid checks one of the three chairs for stability befo sitting down.  11.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: You're Pete Sothow's nephew, huh? Hell, I thought maybe you was someone come to kill me... (he has the cups and he crosses to the fire) ...for somethin' I done in the old days.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (sitting) I could of... easy.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Like I was sayin' you don't look like no meaner than hell cold-blooded damn killer.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Maybe I ain't.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well, Uncle Pete said you was the goddamndest meanest sonofabitch ever lived an' if I ever wanted a partner for a killin', you was the worst one. Meanin' the best. On account of you're cold as snow an' don't have no weak nerve nor fear. Munny serves the coffee gloomily and sits down. It appear his feelings are hurt but The Kid doesn't notices.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: He said that, huh?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I'm a damn killer myself, only I ain't killed so many as you because of my youth. Schofield Kid, they call me.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Schofield? You from Schofield?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (laying his Smith & Wesson Schofield .45 on the table) On account of my Schofield model Smith and Wesson pistol.  12.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well, how about it?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Bein' my partner. I'm headin' North up around the Niobrara in Nebraska. Gonna kill a couple of no good cowboys.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: For cuttin' up a lady. They cut up her face an' cut her eyes out, cut her ears off an' her tits too.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (horrified) Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (pleased with the reaction) Thousand dollars of reward. Five hundred a piece.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Paw, I can't move that damn pig. Will has slipped into the house with Penny in tow and the are both covered with mud and Will is swearing toshow off the stranger.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) No cussin' now, Will. Go on out the pump an' clean up some an' I'll be along. Check them other pens. The two kids back out the door, eyes on the pistol and th stranger, and Munny walks over near the beds with his bac to The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain't like that no more, Kid. Whiskey done it as much as anythin' I guess. (turning to The Kid) I ain't touched a drop in ten years. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My wife, she cured me of it... cured me of drink an' wickedness.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well... you don't look so prosperous. Hell, you could buy her a new dress out of your half. We could kill them two an' you could buy your wife one of them fancy...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: She's passed on, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Been gone near three years now.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (staring stupidly) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Penny in front of the house, looking up at The K who is mounted again and Munny is standing there taking l of The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Don't tell nobody about the reward an' all. Don't need no other gunmen tryin' to collect.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I don't never see nobody anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (riding away) If you was to change your mind, might be you could catch me... due West to the Western Trail an' North to Ogallala. Munny waves at The Kid and for a long moment watches him trot across the flat, grassy fields. Then he turns back t his shabby farm and the squealing pigs and the two childr who are looking up at him.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (turning away) Best we move that pig.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny in the mud and the pig squealing and Will is there pushing too and Munny goes in face first again and when h comes up he slowly wipes mud from his face and, turning, looks across the fields.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON PENNY
dialogues.text: Coming up beside the pen.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Paw... two of them others ...I think they got the fever. Munny frowns and looks off at the horizon, lost in though

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE KID
dialogues.text: Way off in the distance, disappearing on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah's face! The cut-whore. Skeins of criss-crossing raised flesh, a vicious web of scars dominated by her eye that are deep and beautiful. She's hanging clothes on a clothes line on Big Whiskey Hi the gentle slope above the town. Alice, Little Sue, Silky Kate, and Faith are close by, hanging clothes or washing them in the gurgling stream. Faith is the first to glance down the hill toward the tow and to notice. She draws in her breath and turns to Alice and catches her eye and Alice looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The muddy North Road and the two riders, and they are Qui Mike and Davey Bunting leading their ponies in, passing a crudely painted sign that says: "Ordinance 14. No firearms in Big Whiskey. Deposit them a County Office. By Order of Sheriff."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whores on the hill. One by one, with no words exchang they feel the silence and turn and exchange glances and t glance at Delilah. She winces and turns back to hanging clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspecting.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: You boys took a while. Couple more days I was gonna call on the Sheriff. The horses are gathered in front of Greely's and Skinny m among them inspecting them while the two cowboys remain mounted.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: River was swole so we couldn't cross her. Davey is holding the halter of a little paint and when SK starts to inspect the pain, Davey pulls the pony away.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got two of mine. This here one ain't yours. Skinny and Davey lock eyes and Skinny is wondering how fa to push it when SPLAT!... Davey gets a face full of mud. The three men turn to see the whores coming around the si of Greely's, all except Delilah, and they are throwing mu scooping it from the sloppy street and... MIKE gets a hit on the chest and then on the face and he gives an ugly look and wheels his horse and digs in his s and heads North at a trot and mud continues to rain on hi as the whores jeer.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Damn you. (SPLAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't no way to behave. (SPLAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit that. Surprisingly, Davey turns his horse right into the barrag of mud and taking it in the face and on the chest he dismounts. His paint takes a big gob of mud on one eye an Davey wipes the mud off tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: This here pony... I brung it for the lady... the one my partner cut. The whores stop throwing mud abruptly. There is a pause.. and they can see that he is just a kid, and that he is so as hell and that he is about to cry and they are touched, especially Little Sue.  16.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's the best of the lot... better than the ones I give him. (indicating Skinny) She could sell it or... what she wants.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (recovering) A pony!... She ain't got no face left an' you're gonna give her a goddamn mangy pony.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: He ain't m-m-mangy, ma'am, he... SLOP. Davey gets it in the face with a big gob of mud as Alice resumes fire and SPLAT, the paint gets it. Faith and Silky and Kate hesitate just a moment... and th they dig in and start jeering and throwing again and Litt Sue bends down slowly and picks up some mud and then she just stands there with it, almost crying, and watches the cowboy turn away under a barrage of mud and mount his pon and ride out, mud hitting him all over and the women jeer and running after him in the muddy street.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON DELILAH
dialogues.text: Hanging clothes up on the hill and she canhear the shouting in the distance and she turns and looks down with the beautiful eyes and sees the cowboy riding out of town slowly, chased by the jeering women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a photograph of CLAUDIA in Munny's hands. He is inside, kneeling on the floor beside an open truck and he studying reverently the old photo of Claudia, smiling radiantly in her best dress. Finally Munny puts the pictu down and digs in the trunk among folded dresses that belo to her until he feels something metal and he sees the blu steel among the white cloth and then he pulls it out... a old Starr .44 Pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a Mojav coffee tin as Munny places it on the fen behind his sod hut. Munny has the Starr in his right hand and he turns and walks back toward the house 15 yards awa Will and Penny are watching. They know something is going on, but they don't know how to ask what it is. Munny faces the coffee tin and solemnly extends his pisto arm straight out and carefuly sights along the barrel.  17. BAM! A burst of flame and a puff of black smoke from the gun. The Mojav tin hasn't moved. Slowly, carefully, Munny raises the gun again and aims wi great deliberation. BAM! The coffee tin doesn't move. Munny shakes his head slowly in disgust and aims again. BAM! Missed again. Munny gives a quick sheepish glance in the direction of t children. There is a lot of smoke. He aims again and BAM! He misses. Munny is irritated and he aims and fires hastily and flam bursts from the gun and smoke and The tin is unmoved. Will looks at his feet, embarrassed, not wanting to meet father's eyes. Munny stuffs the pistol in his waistband and disappears i the house. Will and Penny look at one another nervously, wondering w happening.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Did Paw used to kill folks? Will doesn't answer and then he looks up because Munny st out of the house again, a sawed off Remington 10 gauge sh in his hands. Munny raises the double barreled weapon to his shoulder a aims carefully and... BARRRROOOOOM! The can flies away in pieces and some of th fence, too.

dialogues.speaker: "CLAUDIA FEATHERS MUNNY
dialogues.text: Born, March 11, 1849 Died, August 6, 1878, aged 29 years, the full enjoyment of that love which constrained her to leave all for Christ and heathen souls Lo, we have left a and followed thee: What shall we leave therefore. 19:25" The headstone is under a couple of shade trees fifty yard from the sod hut.  18. MUNNY is sitting on a rock under the trees looking at the headstone and he has on a cheap black suit now. He twists the hat, tormented... and he starts to say something out loud but he can't because men don't talk to stones. So finally he gets up, slumped in defeat, and he puts a litt bouquet of flowers on the grave and he turns away unhappi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ALBINO MARE snorting and shying, anxious to lose the saddle. Will has her by the halter, holding her with effo in front of the house.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: She ain't hardly a saddle horse no more, Paw. She ain't used to the feel. Munny walks up and puts his hand on Penny's head fondly.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Them flowers, Penny, I could tell your Maw liked them, hear? (turning to Will) Take care of your sister, son. You can kill three chickens if you need, not no more. Keep the hogs that got fever separate if you can. An' if you need help, go see Sally Two-Trees over to Ned Logan's. Then he turns to the mare and shoves a foot in the stirru to mount but the horse shies and Munny goes down in the d looking very undignified. And Penny is horrified and humiliated for her father whom she worships and Will's eyes are big because Munny's coat came open and he caught a quick glimpse of the Starr pist stuck in the waist band.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (brushing himself off, embarrassed) Ain't felt a saddle in a while myself. Then Munny has one foot in the stirrup and the horse star to shy and Munny has to hop around with one foot stirrupe and the other not... and when he tries to swing aboard he falls back...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Easy old gal, easy... And he still can't make it, so to cover his embarrassment talks to the kids while he hops around desperately trying mount.  19.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now this here horse is gettin' even on me... hold on gal... for the sins of my youth... In my youth... before I met... your dear departed mother... I was weak an' givin' to mistreatin' horses an' such. An' this here horse... an' that ole pig, too, I guess... is my comeuppance for my cruelty... At last he is in the saddle and takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Used to be I could cuss an' hurt an animal... til your departed mother, God rest her, showed me the error of my ways. Munny turns the Albino mare and starts out the gate going Weat toward the fields.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) I won't be no longer than a couple of weeks. Remember how the spirit of your departed maw watches over you. Will and Penny are watching him go and Will is fighting b the tears but Penny has lost the battle and she is crying and the horse whinnies.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MUNNY
dialogues.text: Twenty yards away getting up off the ground and trying to catch the shying, prancing horse on foot, his dignity a shambles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice IN PAIN because Skinny is twisting her arm and they are in Alice's room... it is still night... and the other whores are there, scared, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (furious) Where'd you get the money, huh?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (in pain) We ain't got it. We ain't got no money.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: You told them cowboys you had it.  20.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: We was... lyin'.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (lets her go) What you gonna do when somebody comes to collect? (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: FUCK 'EM
dialogues.text: (goes to door, then stops) The kind of people who'll come after that thousand, they won't tolerate if you don't have it. They won't just cut your face up a little. (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on HOT SUN blazing down. BANG BANG BANG, HAMMER ON NAIL and the fingers holding th nail are swollen and purple and then... WHUP Hammer on fl

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, shit an' damn, oh fuck my mother and my father, o damn an' jesus. Little Bill is hopping around in his hat and boots and no else in front of his brand new one story, four room, fram house that hasn't been painted it's so new and doesn't ha a porch yet, though that is being begun... sort of. In fact... the house doesn't look quite right... looks a lit lopsided. Skinny Dubois is standing there, in the clearing wiping h brow and catching his breath and watching Little Bill.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Hit your finger, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (surprised) Huh? Hullo, Skinny. Snuck up on me. (indicating the house proudly) How do you like her?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (looking critically) Heard you done the roof yourself.  21.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Roof? Jesus, Skinny, I done practically every damn thing myself. Roberts boy hauled wood, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: What's all that wood?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) Porch. I'm puttin' a porch on her so's I can puff my pipe of an evening an' drink my coffee an' watch the sun set. Little Bill is back at it, hauling a four by six into position.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder, proudly) You come clear up here just to get a look at her? The train whistle screams loudly below in the valley and turning nervously, Skinny can see a puff of steam above t distant trees.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Them whores... (he pauses, reluctant to go on) Little Bill isn't really paying attention to anything but his house.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Them whores, they been fuckin' an' fuckin' all them cowboys that come into town the last two weeks...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Shit, Skinny, we got railroad barons an' cattle barons, but you' re gonna be the first of the billiard barons.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) ...They been fuckin' 'em, ‘an tellin' every bow-legged one of ‘em how they're payin' a thousand dollars to whatever sonofabitch kills them two boys which cut up Delilah.  22. Little Bill drops the board he's holding up and turns sha to Skinny. Down in the valley the train whistle screams a after a long, tense moment, Little Bill turns and looks o over the valley, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: An' all them cowboys been riding that beef down to Kansas an' Cheyenne?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (unhappily, dropping his eyes) Yup.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: All week?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (apologetically) I didn't hear nothin' till last night.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Word must have got all the way to Texas by now.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (quickly) Oh, shit, Bill, I guess nobody's gonna come clear from Texas.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (sitting down) They really got all that money, them whores?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (sitting beside Bill) You know how women kin lie... I knock "em around a little, ask 'em where the money is, they say they don't have none?...but they coulda squirreled away that much, the five of 'em. Maybe. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: That much, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (hopeful) You could run off them two cowboys.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (sharply) I could run off them whores.  23.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Well, I guess they'll just up an' run anyhow, them two.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (glumly ) Nope. They'll stay out on the Spade country where they got friends. The train whistle screams down in the valley and the trai is chugging in the distance, pulling out, headed South.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Shit, Bill, could be nobody won't come at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLY TWO TREES, weeding under a hot sun. She is an India woman about forty years old, heavy, and she is pulling we from a neat garden near the Logan House and she looks up she sees something and frowns and keeps looking and doesn like what she sees,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN IN THE DISTANCE RIDING AN ALBINO MARE, making his w slowly through the prosperous fields of young corn.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON SALLY
dialogues.text: She looks over at her husband, NED LOGAN, who is working not far away and he seems to "hear" her look because he turns to her and, seeing her troubled expression, he follows her look and he too sees the rider on the Albino mare.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I'll be damned. It's Billy Munny. Ned is about forty, balding, a farmer, but not as seedy looking as his old friend, Bill Munny.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MUNNY
dialogues.text: Trying to dismount and the Albino prancing and Munny staggering and Sally looking at the scene grimly.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Hullo Sally... I... uh, I ain't seen you in near as long as this, uh... as this horse ain't felt the saddle.  24. Munny gets up out of the dust looking uncomfortable and S just stares at him coldly.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (warmly) Come on in outta the sun, Bill. Sally, you see to Bill's horse. Munny nods an uncomfortable thank-you to Sally as Ned lea him toward a house that is very different from Munny's. I is a two story frame house freshly painted and surrounded a well-tended garden, a tool shed, a barn and lush fields As the men disappear into the house Sally leads the Albin toward the barn. Her sharp eyes don't miss the stock of t shotgun where it protrudes slightly from the bedroll. Her eyes seem to see even into the future... and all they see trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on CLEAN CERAMIC COFFEE MUGS as NED takes them from tidy cabinet in his cozy kitchen with the cast iron stove the solid table. Munny is sitting at the table looking moodily into space.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (earnestly) We ain't bad men no more, Bill. Hell, we're farmers.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully) Should be easy killin' em... supposin' they don't run off to Texas first.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (taking the pot from the stove) How long since you shot a gun ata man? (pause) Nine... ten years?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Eleven.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Easy, huh? Hell, I don't know that it was all that easy then... an' we was young an' full of beans. (pouring coffee) Bill... if you was mad at ‘em... if they done you wrong... I could see shootin' 'em...  25.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (looking Ned in the eye) We done stuff before for money, Ned.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (sitting down) Well, we thought we was doin' it for money... (he pauses, remembering) What'd they do anyhow? Cheat at cards, steal some strays, spit ona rich fella?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Cut up a woman. Cut her eyes out, cut her tits off, cut her fingers off... done everythin' but cut up her cunny, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (after chewing on that one) Well, I guess they got it comin'... (and he pauses and looks Munny in the eye) But you wouldn't go if Claudia was alive. It hits Munny like salt in a wound and he just takes it. They both know Ned is right and they think about it silen Finally Munny speaks glumly.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (getting up and going to the door) I guess you wouldn't mind to look in on my youngsters next week. Might be you could help them move a couple of them pigs i they got to separate 'em more. Ned has been thinking about it while Munny's talking, wrestling with it and now Munny is out the door.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: How long you gonna be, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Two weeks, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: This Kid, what's he like?  26. Munny turns and looks at Ned and their eyes meet and Munn realizes Ned is coming.

dialogues.speaker: NED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three ways?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Yup. You still got the Spencer rifle?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (grinning) Yeah, an' I could still hit a bird in the eye flyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny landing with a thud in the dust and picking himself hurriedly and casting a sheepish glance over his shoulder Ned as he makes another awkward effort to mount the mare.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (amazed at this performance) Jesus, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sad, wise eyes of Sally Two Trees as she watches the riders disappearing in the distance. her eyes are saying good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE RIDERS IN THE DISTANCE. One horse is walking and the white one is prancing and shying in an unruly manner whil her rider fights desperately for control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUNSET, and Ned and Munny riding in open country.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: He musta been movin' right along.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: We'll come across him tomorra, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night and the sizzling campfire as Ned empties the grease from the frying pan into the fire. Munny is already lying down, fussing in his blankets to g comfortable and the crickets are chirping up a storm.  27.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Got used to my bed. Ain't gonna feel to home out here.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (getting into his blankets) Well, it ain't just the bed I'm gonna miss. I'm... (he stops suddenly) Hell, Billy, I'm sorry. I didn't mean...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: It ain't nothin', don't fret it. (pause) She don't like it much, you goin' off with me.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Sally?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: She gave me the evil eye.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: It's just... she's a Indian an' Indians ain't... overfriendly.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I ain't blamin' her, Ned, I ain't holdin' it against her. (pause) She knew me back then... an' she seen what a no good sonofabitch I was... an' she won't allow how I've changed. She just don't know how I ain't like that no more.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Well, she...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (urgently) I ain't the same, Ned. Claudia, she... straightened me up, got me clear of the whiskey an' all. Us goin' to do this killin'... that don't mean I'm back to like I was. I just need the money... for a new start... for them youngsters. (long pause) Remember that drover, the one I shot in the mouth so's the teeth come out the back of his head? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long pause) (CONT'D) I dream about him now an' again. I didn't have no reason to shoot him... not one I could remember when I sobered up.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You was a... a crazy sonofabitch.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Nobody liked me... none of the boys. They was scared of me... figured I might shoot 'em out of pure meanness.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You ain't like that no more.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Eagle... he hated my guts. Bonaparte didn't like me none.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Nor Quincy, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Quincy, he was always watchin' me. Scared.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You ain't like that no more.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Hell, no. I'm just a fella now. ain't no different from anyone else no more. After a pause, Ned rolls over to go to sleep and says something kind by way of saying goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Hell, Bill, I always liked you... even back then. Ned settles in his covers and so does Munny and the crick chirp for a long moment but Munny can't sleep with the li

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: No you didn't. You wasn't no different, Ned. (and we...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAYLIGHT and a train whistle SCREAMING.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headline on the newspaper says "President Garfield Wounded." FUZZY, a cowboy, is sitting in the rocking coac reading the paper with great effort, partly because of th motion of the train and partly because Fuzzy can't read v well... but CROCKER, the rough looking cowboy on the seat next to him can't read at all.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER
dialogues.text: All I want to know is what sonofabitch shot him, that's all. Was it one of them John Bull assholes? Across the aisle two well dressed gentlemen are sitting. The one by the window, the lean one in the frock coat and slouch hat, is WW BEAUCHAMP and the one on the aisle, pud pinkcheeked, with neat muttonchop whiskers, wearing a fro coat and waistcoat and a silk slouch hat in spite of the heat, is ENGLISH BOB. English Bob has beady blue eyes, is about thirty-five and pulls constantly on a good cigar.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (in a rich English accent) No, sir, I believe the would-be murderer is a gentleman of French ancestry... or so it would seem. I hope I won't give offense if I observe that the French are known to be a race of assassins, though they can't shoot worth a damn...any Frenchman among the present company excluded of course. Crocker, not liking or understanding the interruption, gi English Bob a hard stare.

dialogues.speaker: FUZZY
dialogues.text: (to Crocker) Says here a fellow by the name of "Gitto." "G-U-I--T..."

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER
dialogues.text: (eyes on Bob) Sounds like a damn John Bull to me. "Gitto." THIRSTY, a cowboy sitting behind Crocker, turns in his se sensing the tension in the air and WW feels it too and sh uneasily... but English Bob is unperturbed and he puffs cheerfully on his cigar.  30.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Well, sirs... again not wishing to give offense... it might be a good idea if the country were to choose a Queen... or even a King ...rather than a president. One isn't as quick to take a shot at a King or a Queen. The majesty of royalty, you see...

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER
dialogues.text: (provocative) Maybe you don't wish to give offense, sir, but you are givin' it pretty thick. This country don't need no queens whatsoever, I guess. Crocker is shifting in his seat so that the revolver in h holster is prominent and there is uneasy stirring among t nearby passengers. A DRUMMER looks around for exits.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, what I heard about Queens...

dialogues.speaker: THURSTON
dialogues.text: Shut up, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER
dialogues.text: (to Thurston) Huh? What's got up your ass, Thirsty? This dude asshole...

dialogues.speaker: THURSTON
dialogues.text: (to Crocker, but his eyes on Bob) Might be the "dude" is English Bob ...the one who works for the Union Pacific shootin' Chinamen. Might be he wants for some dumb cowboy to touch his pistol... so's he can shoot him down. English Bob, unperturbed, just pulls on his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER
dialogues.text: (sobered) That a fact, mister? You English Bob?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (affably) Why don't we shoot some turkeys, friend? Ten shots... a dollar a turkey. I'll shoot for the Queen, and you can shoot for... whomever.  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turkeys bursting from long Nebrasks grass as the train wh screams. BLAM! A turkey plummets to earth. BLAM! Another goes down.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: On the swaying platform between cars, his pistol smoking BOB brings it up again fast and sights and BLAM! AN EXPLOSION OF FEATHERS plummeting down and disappearing the long grass.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE PLATFORM
dialogues.text: Where WW Beauchamp, Crocker, Thurston, Fuzzy and the nerv Drummer, in a cheap bowler, are standing. They are all impressed with the fact that English Bob is one hell of a shot with a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (to Crocker) I believe that's eight for me... to one for you. A matter of seven of your American dollars.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKER
dialogues.text: (grudgingly counting silver dollars) Pretty damn good shootin'.... (daring) for a John Bull.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (accepting the money cheerfully) No doubt your aim was affected by your grief over the injury to your uh... president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bawling cattle milling in the pens south of Big Whiskey, the train hissing and steaming at a standstill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two leather valises and a leather rifle case as MUDDY CHANDLER tosses them on his mud wagon, a sort of open stagecoach. The scene is one of chaos as the train steams and hisses and baggage is tossed off and more is tossed on.  32.

dialogues.speaker: CHANDLER
dialogues.text: It's a nickel up to Big Whiskey, gentlemen. Ww hands Chandler the money and, as he and English Bob cl into the mud wagon, they are accosted by GERMANY JOE SCHU who runs the livery stable and does horse business with railway passengers on the side.

dialogues.speaker: GERMANY JOE
dialogues.text: I godd nize horzes I zell you, boyce. Nize prizes for Independence Day, boyce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English Bob and W riding in the mud wagon, bouncing uncomfortably in spite of the slow pace, and eating dust sweating profusely.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (irritably) It's the climate does it. That and the infernal distances.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: Does what?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Induces people to shoot persons in high places. (mopping his brow with his handkerchief) It's a savage country. That's the second one shot in twenty years. It's uncivilized shooting people of substance. The mud wagon rattles past the South Road sign. It is sim to the one of the North Road and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deputy ANDY RUSSELL stepping out of the County Office as mud wagon clatters to a stop in front of the Big Whisky I Andy is just twenty, a good looking kid with a badge on h vest and a holstered pistol. He watches the passengers cl out of the mud wagon and, as English Bob alights, his fro coat parts and gives ANDY just the quickest glimpse of a holstered pistol under the coat.  33.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Pardon me, gentlemen, but local ordinance obliges you to surrender your sidearms to proper authority for the duration of your visit. ww looks at English Bob and English Bob turns and looks A up and down very coolly.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Proper authority eh? (breezily) Well, sir... neither my companion nor I carry firearms on our persons. Rather, we trust in the goodwill of our fellow man and the forbearance of reptiles. And English Bob gives a smart bow, turns with a swirl of coat-tails that allows a brief glimpse of not one, but tw holstered pistols, and marches off. As WW follows English Bob, he glances nervously back to see what young Andy wil do but Andy just stares nonplussed. In that quick glimpse Andy saw how the weapons were tied down with thongs, mean the owner wanted a quick pull... and this shit is out of league.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KER-CHICK, CLACK, A HENRY RIFLE COCKED and the action che Andy is cleaning the weapon in the County Office.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Unarmed, my ass. SHUCK, KA-CHAK. CHARLEY HECKER breaks open a single barre shotgun and moves a shell in.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (wiping his brow nervously) Christ, it's hot.

dialogues.speaker: FATTY
dialogues.text: ((cheerfully) If I'm gonna get shot, I druther it was hot then cold. Everythin' hurts more in the cold. Fatty is sitting in a chair in front of the empty jail ce cleaning a revolver, oblivious to the tension.

dialogues.speaker: FATTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know how if you hit your thumb in the cold, how it...?  34.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Shut up, Fatty.

dialogues.speaker: FATTY
dialogues.text: I only said... Outside a horse clatters up fast and Andy jumps nervously the window.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: Clyde's back.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Little Bill with him?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (worried) Shit. Clyde bursts in the door. He is wearing two gun-belts crossed, with a holster on each side. Since he has only o arm, he carries one pistol butt forward and the other but back.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: You boys clean my Remington?

dialogues.speaker: FATTY
dialogues.text: (holding it up) Cleaned an' loaded.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Where's Little Bill for Christ sake?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (inspecting the pistol) Ha. He was building his fucking porch.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Building his porch!

dialogues.speaker: FATTY
dialogues.text: If you was to get shot, Andy, would you like it better to be a hot day or...?

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (sharply) I ain't gonna get shot.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (to Clyde) He's coming ain't he?  35.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (ejecting shells) "Course he's coming.

dialogues.speaker: FATTY
dialogues.text: Hey, I just loaded her. Watcha doin?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I don't trust nobody to load my guns, not for a shootin'.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Little Bill? He didn't say nothing. Like I said, he was buildin' his porch. Have you seen that thing?

dialogues.speaker: FATTY
dialogues.text: (sulking) It was all loaded. Jesus, Clyde, you got three pistols an' only one arm for Christ sake.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (to Fatty) I just don't wanna get killed for lack of shootin' back. (to Charley) You know there ain't a straight angle in that whole goddamn porch... or in the whole house for that matter. He's the worst fucking carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (worried) He didn't say nothin', huh?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (putting the 3rd pistol in his belt) Asked what they looked like, that's all. Christ, maybe he's tough but he sure ain't no carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Maybe he ain't so tough. Clyde looks up, surprised. There is a sudden silence.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (blurting it) He seem like... like he was... scared?  36.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (amazed) Little Bill? Him scared?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: We never seen him up against any... like these ones... killers.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (looking at the frightened faces of Charley and Andy) Little Bill come out of Kansas an' Texas, boys. He worked them tough towns.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (ashamed) Just wondered. Anybody could be scared. Andy drops his eyes and looks away from Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (with meaning) No. He wasn't scared, boys. He just ain't a good carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English Bob, delighting in the smooth feel of his freshly shaved pink cheeks, climbs cheerfully out of the barber c still chattering at the poor BARBER.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: ...can see that there's a dignity in royalty... a majesty... that precludes the likelihood of assassination. The Barber is applying his little whisk broom to Bob's waistcoat while WW pulls out his purse to make payment.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Why, if you were to point a pistol at a King or a Queen, sir, I can assure you your hand would shake as though palsied...

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: (looking at Bob's pistols) I wouldn't point no pistol at nobody, sir.  37.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (putting on his frock coat over his guns) A wise policy. But if you did, I can assure you, the sight of royalty would cause you to dismiss all thoughts of bloodshed and stand... in awe. (pause) Whereas, a president... I mean, why not shoot a president? The Barber doesn't know how to take this guy, and just og him.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now this Strawberry Alice person, tell me again.

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Down the street and across. Greely's Beer Garden and Billiard parlor. Just ask for Alice and say you want a game of billiards.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (about to exit) Billiards, eh? Even though I don't really wish to play?

dialogues.speaker: BARBER
dialogues.text: Don't matter. They burned the table in '78 for firewood.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Ah, I see. Ww has already stepped out and English Bob follows him ou the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English Bob steps out the door.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Come on, W. Let's... Something's wrong! There is a funny quiet and WW is froze like a ramrod. English Bob looks around.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CHARLIE HECKER
dialogues.text: Ten yards to Bob's right, pointing a 12 gauge shotgun and Fatty Rossiter a few feet away pointing his old Enfield.  38.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON ANDY RUSSELL
dialogues.text: On Bob's left, pale and tense, pointing his Henry, and Cl Ledbetter kneeling near him, leveling one of his pistols.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Standing ten yards away in the empty dusty street where t Fourth of July flags are flapping.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Hullo, Bob. Boys, this here is English Bob.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Shit and fried eggs.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Been a long time, Bob. You run out of Chinamen?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (recovering his composure) Little Bill, I thought you were dead. I see you shaved off your chin whiskers.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (feeling his chin) Well, I was always tasting the soup two hours after I et it.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: Empty, silent.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW FACES IN THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Of the Blue Bottle restaurant. EGGS ANDERSON, TOM LUCKINB MRS. PEEVEY, HOPPITY THOMAS, peering out.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ALICE, KATE AND LITTLE SUE IN GREELY'S WINDOW
dialogues.text: And, in the open doorway, ready to duck for cover, Skinny and Germany Joe Schultz and PADDY MCGEE, the cooper.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: What I heard was that you fell off your horse drunk and broke your neck.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: I heard that one myself, Bob. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hell, I even thought I was dead til I found out it was just I was in Nebraska. (pause) Who's your friend?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: WwW Beauchamp... Little Bill Daggett and... "friends."

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (nervous) From N-n-newton?... and H-hays and A- a-abilene?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (dryly) The same. Charley is taking all this in wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: You work for the railroads too, Mister Beauchamp?

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (scared to death) N-no. I wr-wr-wr-write... I wr-wr- write...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Letters?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Books. He's my biographer.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (fighting amazement) And WW is reaching for a pocket.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW
dialogues.text: Andy and Charley and Clyde and Fatty tensing to fire.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do it, WwW. Ww freezes, terrified... and a puddle of urine forms at h feet.  40.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: It's only a b-b-b-book...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (his pistol half-drawn) A book, huh? (returning his pistol and glancing at the piss) I guess that means you can read...An' I guess you boys seen them signs about surrendering your firearms... But then, like you told old Andy there, you ain't armed, are you, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Not really... (shrugging) Maybe a couple of Peacemakers... (bargaining) I imagine you could overlook those, eh, Bill? If you didn't see them... or hear them?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (cold as ice) I guess not, Bob. I don't like guns around. With a sardonic glance at the arsenal trained on him Engl Bob gives a shrug and holds open his coat in surrender, exposing two fancy holstered pistols. Little Bill gives Andy a head signal and Andy steps forwa and takes the pistols from English Bob's holsters.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charley, see what kind of "books" Mister Beauchamp is packing... but watch you don't get we

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (to Andy) Be careful with those, sonny. Onlookers are stepping out of doorways now and moving tim into the street forming a large semi-circle. The whores a among them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: No shit, Little Bill, all he's got is this here book. Charley holds up a dime novel with a lurid cover showing gentleman in a top hat protecting a woman with his body w  41. firing two pistols at seven disheveled looking "Western types." The title is "The Duke of Death."

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (reading with effort) The... Duck of Death.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: D-d-d-duke. The D-d-duke of Death. English Bob starts to go but Little Bill puts a hand on h shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Give me the .32, Bob. Furious, English Bob turns and looks into Bill's eyes and then, seeing no alternative, opens his vest esposing a sm pistol.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: You leave me at the mercy of my enemies.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (taking the pistol) Enemies, Bob? You been talking about the Queen again? On Independence Day? A lot of the tension has gone out of the occasion and the crowd is beginning to murmur and people are starting to m and a couple of kids are running when suddenly... CRUNCH! English Bob's face seems to cave in with the forc of Little Bill's fist and Bob literally flies backward an slams into the side of the barber shop.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW
dialogues.text: Alice gasping... Andy's jaw drops... Little Sue's eyes bulge... Charley gulps.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Slumped against the wall, blood pouring from his unhinged jaw, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Wh... what... ? Little Bill walks calmly up to him and WHAM... kicks him hard in the chest.  42.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW SILKY
dialogues.text: Having a hard time swallowing and Mrs. Peevey turning awa and Eggs horrified and Alice's scared face.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: Bloody, on all fours, pulling a knife from his waistcoat. but the whole effort is painful and hopeless. He hasn't a chance. Little Bill looks down at him for a moment from his enorm height, watching the smaller man's pitiful effort, then SLAM!... Little Bill kicks him in the ribs hard and you c hear air going out of Bob, and Bill steps hard on Bob's k hand and the bones crunch loudly.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW
dialogues.text: Ww, white as a ghost and Andy is trying not to vomit. The is the sound of another brutal blow.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW
dialogues.text: English Bob on all fours in the dusty street now, barely conscious. KA-WHUMP! Little Bill kicks him again, not angrily, but h

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: I guess you think I'm kickin' you, Bob... but it ain't so. (WHAM, another kick) What I'm doin' is talkin', hear? I'm talkin' to all them villains down in Kansas an' them villains in Cheyenne... (WHUMP )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lettin' em know there ain't no whores' gold... Little Bill turns and looks hard at the whores and Alice sick from the violence and Little Sue is biting her lip a Silky has tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (turning back to Bob and kicking him) ...an' how if there was... how they wouldn't want to come lookin' for it anyhow. Little Bill looks down with eyes as cold as ice and Engli Bob grovels in the bloody dust, barely conscious.  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open country under a hot sun and Munny and Ned riding the horses at a walk and the saddles creaking and birds chirp in the five foot high grass. It is late morning in Northe Kansas and they have been riding since dawn, mostly in silence, but Ned has something on his mind and he glances Munny and frowns and then finally he blurts his question.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Say, Bill... You ever... ever go into town... an' all?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (surprised at the question) Sure, I got to. Got to get supplies.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: No. I mean... (embarrassed) ...an' get yourself a woman? You know? Munny looks away quickly, embarrassed, and it seems like isn't going to answer and then, when he finally does, he keeps his eyes on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Naw. Naw, I don't ever go into town for that. (pause) A man like me... A man like me can't get no woman but one he's gonna pay for... an' that ain't right... buyin' flesh. (looking at Ned) Claudia, God rest her soul, she wouldn't have wanted me doin' nothin' like that, me bein' a father, an' all. (he looks away again)

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (rhetorically) Whaddaya do, just use your hand?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (after a nervous glance at Ned) Sometimes... yeah. (looking at the horizon) I don't miss it all that much. Ned is shaking his head, wondering at the transformation his old friend when...  44. CRACK! A RIFLE SHOT and the Albino mare rears violently, whinnying and hurling Munny out of the saddle and... Ned's roan bolts at full speed, Ned barely staying aboard CRACK! another shot.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MUNNY
dialogues.text: On all fours in the tall grass. He feels his forehead and wipes away a little blood, and shakes his head to clear it. Then he hears rustling in the long grass and he whirls an pulls the Starr out of his belt and sitting back he aims where he heard the noise and he pulls back the hammer wit loud click.

dialogues.speaker: NED'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Billy. Billy.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (lowering the pistol, relieved) Yeah. Ned crawls out of the grass next to Munny.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Some fucker's shootin' at us.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (alarmed, seeing blood) He hit you?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Naw. I bumped my head fallin' off of my horse. CRACK, another shot. Ned looks puzzled and he lifts his head up and tries to look around without exposing himself A hundred yards away Ned can see a clump of four or five trees and there is a little cloud of black smoke still ha in the air there and then a sudden flash of fire, smoke a

dialogues.speaker: CRACK
dialogues.text: Ned doesn't even duck, he just frowns.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: He ain't shootin' our way no more. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (indicating the left) He's shootin' over that way. Who's he shootin' at over that way?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Beats the hell out of me.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You suppose maybe we're in somebody's field?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I didn't see nothin' planted. CRACK. Another shot. Ned ducks urgently.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Fuck, he's shootin' at us again. CRACK, CRACK, CRACK.

dialogues.speaker: NED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jesus, he's shootin' up the whole fucking horizon. Munny is thinkinh about it, has an idea, weighs it and gi it atry.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (shouting) HEY.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You're marking us, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) HEY, KID.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Kid? The Kid's shootin at us?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Why would the Kid shoot at us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid rifle at his cheek is crouched behind one of the trees. His horse is standing nearby.  46.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Kid, is that you? It's me, Bill Munny. The Kid is frowning and finally he makes up his mind.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (shouting) YEAH. IT'S ME.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don't shoot at us no more, okay? The Kid is peering around the tree and squinting ferociou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The field. It is one big blur. He can't see worth a shit. The Kid squinting and peering and worrying.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ned Logan. My old partner, Ned Logan. Don't you shoot no more, okay? The Kid doesn't like it, he's nervous and twitching, tryi desperately to see what's going on out there.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're gonna collect our horses an' come on over. You ain't gonna shoot no more, are you?

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MUNNY
dialogues.text: Bedraggled and sweaty, walking into the clump of trees leading his horse and Ned, behind him, leading his roan and looking just as bad.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Had to chase the damn horse a mile. The Kid is sitting under the shade tree looking sullen.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (angry) ; What was you shootin' at us for, anyhow?  47.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Thought you was followin' me.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Well, we was. Like you said, I changed my mind an'...

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Wasn't nothin' said about no partner.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Well, this here's Ned Logan...Ned, this here's the Schofield Kid, nephew of Pete Sothow an’...

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I seen two fellas followin' me, I guessed they come to kill me. (pause) We didn't talk about no other fella.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (squatting in front of The Kid, talking in a persuasive tone) Well, now Kid, there's two of these cowboys, ain't that so? Better there's three of us... maybe them cowboys got friends. Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I was gonna kill them two by myself. It don't take three. Ned walks over to where The Kid's rifle is leaning agains the tree and The Kid is watching nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Now Ned's a hell of a shot with a rifle. Hell, he can hit a bird in the eye flyin'.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (picking up The Kid's rifle) Better'n you anyhow, Kid. You wasn't comin' close.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Keep your damn hands offa that rifle, Mister. The Kid is touching his pistol and Ned puts the rifle dow annoyed.  48.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I was only checkin' it for you. Thought maybe somethin' was bent.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Nothin's bent.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Well, you was shootin' every which way an'...

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (to Munny) You gonna share your half with him?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Three ways, I figured.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (to Ned) Sorry, Ned. Guess I wasted your time. See ya, Kid! Munny turns to go and Ned gives The Kid a disgusted look turns away.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (to Munny) You're goin' back with him?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (turning) He's my partner. He don't go, I don't. Ned is mounted and Munny starts to mount too, but the mar is as reluctant as ever, shying and prancing while MUNNY hops awkwardly with one foot in the stirrup.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: What's it come to, three ways? Munny turns and looks at The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them riding across open country. The Kid loo like he still has a thorn up his ass and the only sound i the creaking of saddles. Storm clouds are gathering behind them on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Oh shit.  49. And The Kid looks back but of course he can't figure out what it is they saw.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: What the hell are you pissin' about, I'd like to know?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (astonished) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well, what were you lookin' at anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Lookin' at?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Clouds, Kid. We was lookin' at them clouds on account of we got a storm ridin' up our ass.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (looking back) Oh, them. (petulantly) Hell, I seen them. Ned frowns and looks at The Kid and something is botherin Ned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dry stream bed and the three men are riding single file now with The Kid in the lead but Ned has been thinking an trotting with his horse, he pulls alongside The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You was right to change your mind, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (surly, suspicious) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (proudly) I'm a damn good shot. (looking up) See that hawk up there? I could kill that hawk with one shot. VIEW on the empty sky. There isn't any hawk. VIEW on Munny who is right beside them is looking up and doesn't see any hawk and he looks at Ned like he thought was crazy and he frowns.  50. The Kid just looks up and squints and looks ahead at the trail and keeps riding.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Hell, I could hit it too if I didn't mind wasting a shot. And Munny looks up again, amazed, because they must be cr both of them. And Ned reins his horse hard.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: There ain't no hawk up there, Kid. And the Kid reins and turns and he locks eyes with Ned. H knows he's been found out.

dialogues.speaker: NED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can't see worth a shit, can you? The Kid is furious, his eyes flick around and he spots something and he pulls out the Schofield.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: See them fucking turtles?

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THREE TURTLES
dialogues.text: Making their way up the stream bed ten yards away.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE KID
dialogues.text: His Schofield spitting fire and smoke BLAM, BLAM.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE TURTLE
dialogues.text: BLAM, the third turtle exploding and following the other to oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (impressed) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (impressed but holding back) How far kin you see?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Far enough.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: We ain't goin' to Nebraska on no turtle hunt. A hundred yards?  51.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (testing) See that scrub oak yonder?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (furious) Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (to Munny) He's blind, for Chri...

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (pointing his pistol at Ned) I ain't blind, you asshole.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Now hold on, boys, hold on. Now, Kid, you kin see fifty yards, can't you?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Bet your ass I kin see fifty yards an' I kin shoot this sonofabitch...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Easy, Kid, easy. (looking Ned in the eye) Now, you hear that, Ned? The Kid can see fifty yards fine, hear?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Fifty yards ain't bad. (glancing at the horizon) Guess we better get along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STORM CLOUDS building behind them on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: A BOOK
dialogues.text: The lurid cover, "The Duke of Death" by W. W. Beauchamp.  52. Little Bill is looking at the cover, his feet propped on desk in the county office. It is night and the office is lit with an oil lamp.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (referring to the book) Them boys look like real hard cases. Did you kill all seven of ‘em dead, Bob... or did you just wing some of "em? English Bob is lying on his back on a cot in the little c a few feet away. He turns his head toward Little Bill and his swollen face is horrible to behold. Of course, he doe answer except with the nasty eye.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That is you there, ain't it, Bob? The Duck of Death?

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (daring) Uh... Duke. Ww is in the little cell next to English Bob's.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah... Duke. Well, Bob, you always was hell an' Jesus with a pistol... but seven of ‘em, an' you protectin' the lady too... How'd you do it? English Bob just turns his malignant stare away but WW sc up his courage and asserts himself... sort of.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: Uh... It's... uh... generally considered desirable in the publishing business to... ah... take certain license in depicting the cover scene... for... ah... purposes involving the... ah, market place.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Well, Mister Beauchamp... from what I read of this here book, I'd have to say the writin' ain't a whole lot different from the pitcher.  53.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (sweating, but with dignity) Uh... I can assure you, Mister Daggett... the events described within are based... on the accounts of eye witnesses and...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (opening the book) Meaning the duck himself, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: Duke.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (harshly) Duck, I says. (reading badly) "You have insulted the honor of this beautiful woman, Corcoran," said the duck. "You must apologize." But Two Gun Corcoran would have none of it and, cursing, he reached for his pistols and would have killed them but The Duck was faster and hot lead blazed from his smoking sixguns." (he tosses the book on the desk, disgusted)

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (with dignity) I believe that to be an accurate description of the events, sir... albeit there is a certain poetry to the language which...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (standing up) Well, Mister Beauchamp, I was at the Blue Bottle Saloon in Wichita the night English Bob killed Corky Corcoran... an' I didn't see you there... nor no woman, nor no two- gun shooters nor nothin' like that.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (amazed) You were there? ww looks to English Bob for confirmation but Bob's stare just gets nastier. Little Bill is warming to the subject though, standing in front of the cell.  54.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
