dialogues.text: First off... Corky didn't carry two pistols, though he should of.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: But he was called...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Some folks did call Old Corky "Two Gun" but not because he was sportin' two pistols but because he had a dick so big it was longer than the barrel on that Walker Colt he carried. An' the only insultin' he done was stickin' that big dick of his in some French Lady that Old Bob was sweet on... Well, one day Corky walked into the Blue Bottle and before he knows what's happening Bob takes a shot at him... and misses on account of he's drunker than hell. Ww is fascinated and he looks to Bob and BOB'S eye is bla and he looks back at Little Bill who is beginning to act the scene.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, that bullet whizzin' by panicked Corky, an' he done the wrong thing! Pulled his gun in such a damn hurry he shot off his own toe. Meantime, Bob aims good and squeezes off another... but he's so drunk he misses again an' hits the thousand dollar mirror behind the bar. Well, now the Duck of Death is good as dead "cause this time Corky does right an' aims real good, no hurry...

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (beside himself) And?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Bam! That Walker Colt blew up in his hand... which was a failing common to that model. Now if Corky would have really had two guns instead of just a big dick he could have defended himself to the end.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: You... you mean... (looking at Bob) English Bob killed him while...?  55.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Well he wasn't gonna wait for Corky to grow no new hand. He walked over real close, bein' drunk, an' shot him through the liver. Www stares first at English Bob and then at Little Bill, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night in the woods and Ned fussing around with his blanke not far from the campfire.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (irritably) No sir, I did not give up robbin' an' stealin' on account of I got religion. I give it up ‘cause I got too old for all this here nature. Munny is lying in his blankets a few feet away, exhausted and dirty and not a bit interested in Ned's complaints.

dialogues.speaker: NED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I give it up 'cause I hate sleepin' out in the air... fuckin' sticks in my food... an' fuckin' bugs in my food... an' fuckin' rocks under my back... (crawling into the blankets) Shit, I sure do miss my fuckin' bed.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (irritably) Yeah... you said that last night.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Last night I said I missed my fuckin' wife... tonight I just miss my fuckin' bed. Lightning flashes and a horse whinnies and then the thund cracks and rolls.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you're gonna miss your fuckin' roof soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horses, shying and skittish, and The Kid is rubbing h face tenderly on the Morgan and whispering in a soothing voice.  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny and Ned lying near the campfire and The Kid walks u and starts to fix his blankets. He looks at Munny thoughtfully. Something's bothering him and finally he blurts it out as he climbs into his own blankets.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Say, Bill. That business in Jackson County... did that really happen? I mean how they say it happened?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: What business?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (a frown, a pause, then...) An' how there was two deputies up close pointin' rifles at you... had you dead to rights... an' how you pulled out a pistol an' blew them both away to hell... an' only took a scratch yourself. (pause) Uncle Pete told me he never seen nothin' like it, shootin' your way out of a scrape like that.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Well... I don't recollect.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (amazed and dubious) You don't recollect! The Kid doesn't know whether he's been rebuffed or what, seeing after a moment that his conversation with Munny is not getting anywhere he decides to have a try at Ned.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say, Ned... ?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (curt) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: How many men you killed? (after a long pause) Ain't you gonna answer?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I don't like the question.  57.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (indignant ) Well, I gotta know what kind of fellas I'm ridin' with, don't I? In case of a scrape.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: How many you killed, Kid?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Five. I killed five of ‘em. (pause) That counts a Mexican I killed. (pause) He come at me with a knife. There is a long pause and then a flash of lightning and a roll of thunder and the nervous whinnies of the horses.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Get some sleep, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You boys are crotchety as a couple of hens. Just then the rain starts and it sizzles in the campfire the horses snort and Ned covers his head with his blanket

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Aw shit!

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: Actually, then, Mister Corcoran was faster on the draw than the D... English Bob? Ww is sitting at Little Bill's desk writing furiously wit quill pen. It is still night and Little Bill is lounging a chair and English Bob is moaning and snoring in the cel

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Faster? Fast was his mistake. If he hadn't of been in such a goddamn hurry he would not have shot off his toe with his first shot and he would have killed old Bob. (lecturing) See, son, bein' a good shot an' bein' quick with a pistol... that don't do no harm... but it ain't much next to bein' cool. Little Bill pulls out his pistol very deliberately... not slowly, but not like a Hollywood fast draw.  58.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A man who will keep his head an' not get rattled under fire... he will kill you like as not. Little Bill is pointing his pistol, aiming.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: But if the other fellow is quicker and fires first...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: He will be hurryin' and he will miss. That there is as fast as I can pull an' aim an' hit anythin' more'n ten feet away... unless it's a barn.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: But... if he doesn't miss?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (laughing and holstering his pistol) Then he will kill you. That is why there are so few dangerous men like old Bob there... an' like me. It ain't so easy to shoot a man anyhow... an' if the sonofabitch is shootin' back at you... well, it'll unnerve most fellas. (struck with an idea) Look here, let me show you somethin'. (he reaches into a drawer in the desk and pulls out a pistol) See this here pistol? ww looks at the pistol uneasily and over in the cell Engl Bob's one eye opens and he moves his head slightly becaus he senses something is happening. Little Bill holds the pistols out to Ww.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take it. (WW hesitates) Go on, take a hold. Nervously WW accepts the gun as though it were hot. Littl Bill pulls some keys out of a drawer and tosses them on t desk.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Them's the keys. All you gotta do is shoot me an' you an' English Bob can ride out free as birds.  59.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (shaking) Is... is it... loaded?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Wouldn't be no good if it wasn't. You got to cock it though. ww looks nervously over at English Bob and Bob's eye says "Do it, do it, do it." Ww gulps and he pulls back the hammer and stands up and l at Bob again and Bob is nodding "Yes, yes, do it."

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: An' you got to point it. (pause) Go on, point it. Slowly, with trembling hand WW raises the gun and points at Little Bill who looks calmly back at him.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All you gotta do is pull on the trigger, mister. WwW gulps and sweat comes off his forehead and he points shaking gun and Bob nods "Yes" and WW bites his lip and then... Ww lowers the gun slowly. He can't do it. He wipes his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hot, ain't it? (reaching for the gun) You never even put your finger on the trigger. Little Bill is reaching for the pistol but WW has a frightening idea and instead of giving up the pistol he s backward toward the cell.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: What if... what if I gave it to... him. (and he indicates Bob) Little Bill's eyes narrow like slits and tension fills the air.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Go ahead... give it to him. English Bob's eye lights up in anticipation and he tries get up on one elbow.  60.

dialogues.speaker: _ WW
dialogues.text: (gulping) R-r-r-really? You r-r-really w-w- want...?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (like ice) Give it to him. English Bob is sitting up and reaching for the gun and hi eye is on Little Bill and WW reaches out with a shaking h and ENGLISH BOB'S hand just touches the gun and... Little Bill drops his right hand to his own gun and grips the butt and... ENGLISH BOB hesitates, his gaze locked with LITTLE BILL'S and the two men eye each other. Then, furious, ENGLISH BO withdraws his hand... empty.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (grinning) Guess he don't want it, Mister Beauchamp. Little Bill accepts the pistol from the trembling W and, looking straight into ENGLISH BOB'S angry eye, LITTLE BIL ejects five cartridges from the chambers of the pistol.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You was right not to take it, Bob. I would of killed you. WwW collapses into a chair and wipes sweat from his brow.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We could use some rain, eh, Mister Beauchamp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BARRRRROOM! THUNDER, LIGHTNING, RAIN IN SHEETS and the Al mare rearing and screaming and Munny landing in the mud.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: You fucking no-good goddamn shitfaced pig fucking dirty whore. It is daylight but the rain is so thick you can't see mor than five feet and Munny crawls up out of the mud wearing slicker and looking like hell, already full of remorse fo his outburst. Ned rides up out of the rain leading Munny's horse and Mu tries to mount again.  61.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it, old gal. The Albino rears but Ned is helping and he holds the hors and then grabs the seat of Munny's muddy pants and half s him into the saddle. Up ahead, barely visible in the rain, The Kid is holding back his horse impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LITTLE LATER. RAIN. Ned and Munny riding side by side through the downpour and The Kid twenty yards ahead, bare visible. Munny looks like shit and Ned looks at him with concern, deliberates, then reaches into his saddle bag an pulls out a bottle of whiskey and offers it.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I brung this for when we had to kill them fellows. (Munny glances at it and looks away) I guess we could use some now.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Not for me. I don't touch it no more.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (exasperated) God damn it, Bill, it's rainin'.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I know it's rainin', (looking ahead) Give the Kid a drink, why dontcha? Ned takes a long pull on the bottle, re-corks it and puts in his saddle bag. He looks sympathetically at his friend hunched unhappily in his saddle.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You think the Kid really killed five men? Munny just shrugs and looks back at the trail and keeps riding.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (after a while) No.  62.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: What he was talkin' about... how them deputies had the drop on you an' Pete...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I remember how there was three of them deputies you shot... not two.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (dismissing it) Well, I ain't like that no more, Ned. I ain't no crazy, killin' fool.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (after a while) You still think it'll be easy shootin' them cowboys? Munny shrugs and looks straight ahead into the rain. Of course, it won't be easy... and they both know it.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: If we don't drown first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blazing hot day and English Bob's battered face staring out of the mud wagon which is being loaded up by Chandler In the distance the train whistle toots eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (to Chandler) Give them keys to the conductor and tell him he can loose the cuffs off of Bob soon as he's out of the county. Little Bill is standing beside the mud wagon and WW is standing next to him and a little knot of onlookers forms semi circle.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: (talking through closed teeth) Mmmm pistols.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Little Bill unwraps a cloth and produces the ivory-handle peacemakers... smashed and hopelessly bent. And he gives them to Bob and looks him in his one furious eye.  63.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess you know, Bob, how if I see you again I'll just start shootin' right off an' figure it's self- defense. That's fine with English Bob. He glares back and the two men understand each other perfectly and then Chandler whi the horses and the wagon starts to roll.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain't stealin' your biographer, Bob. Stayin' on was his idea. And WwW stands there beside Little Bill and gives Boba shiteating look and English Bob just glares and rolls awa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the mud wagon rattles down the dusty street English Bo sticks his horrid swollen face out the window and screams insanely:

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH BOB
dialogues.text: A plague on you! A plague on the whole stinking lot of you! You're uncivilized vermin, without laws or morals! You're worthless savages! I curse you! You're cursed! Cursed! The whores, fanning themselves on Greeley's porch, stare dumbfounded as the madman rolls by raving. Then he's gone All that remains is the sound of his ranting, diminishing the distance and a cloud of dust settling on the hot stre Sitting next to Faith on the porch, Alice fans herself gr

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Nobody's gonna come.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: After what Little Bill done to the Englishman. Skinny steps out the door and blinks in the dazzling ligh and wipes his face.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Delilah, them tables ain't clean. Can't you get 'em clean? Delilah gets up and goes in, angrily brushing past Skinny the doorway.  64.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (after her) Well, if you'd cover up your face, maybe somebody'd want to fuck with you an' you wouldn't have to do all the cleanin'. (to the others) Whaddaya call them things that cover the face?

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: (looking straight ahead) A veil.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, a veil. Christ it's hot. There is a distant roll of thunder and Skinny looks off a the Southern horizon where storm clouds are gathering.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (listlessly) Rain's coming.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: (emphatically) Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER AND LIGHTNING and the train chugging through the storm. A second flash of lightning reveals three drenched riders near the tracks and one of them is having trouble controlling his white horse. Of course it is Munny and as he tries to hold the shying mare a flash of lightning lights up a passing railroad co and Munny gets just a glimpse of a strange battered face the window. The Kid is handing the whiskey bottle back to Ned and Ned offers it to Munny again.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You sure, Bill? And Munny just shakes his head and wipes rain from his ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT AND RAIN and The Kid is chuckling drunkenly and han the bottle back to Ned who looks at it and tilts it way b They are riding along the South road in the dark.  65.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) I left you some... about a drop. Munny is hunched in his saddle, shivering, his teeth chattering.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You alright, Bill? Munny doesn't look alright. He looks like shit... looks sick. He doesn't answer and Ned looks worried and takes t last drops from the bottle and tosses it in the road near the ordinance sign which is too dark to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice's room at night, the sound of rain beating hard on roof. Alice is playing cards with Silky and Faith when Li Sue sticks her head in the door.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: A fella's askin' for you, Alice.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Tonight? You ain't joshin'?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: (looking behind her) This way, mister. Silky and Faith pick up the cards to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Must be randy as hell to come out in this shit. And then they look up because a water soaked young man wi very few front teeth and a ragged stubble is standing in doorway squinting. It is the Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DRIP DRIP DRIP. A chamber pot on the floor of Little Bill house collecting water from a leak in the roof and Little Bill is walking about in stocking feet, making a speech.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: "No," he says, "you are wrong Little Bill. That there is no Curly J but a bobbed J." He had worked it over, you see? WW Beauchamp is sitting in a chair scratching frantic not with a quill pen... and a splotch of water hits the paper and he glances up because there is a new leak.  66.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (continuing, oblivious) "Jim," I says, "You are a liar anda horsethief." Now -- when he seen them others wasn't gonna help him none -- he started in to cryin' and sobbin' and sayin'... (mimicking) "Don't kill me, Little Bill, don't kill me, please don't kill me." ww is trying to write and trying to slide away from the l without interrupting Little Bill who is delighting in his own narration, oblivious to the new leak.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in his own voice) "Well, Jim," I says, "it makes me sick to see a man struttin' around and packin' two pistols an' a Henry rifle and cryin' like a baby." ww Did you... kill him?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: No,... but I can't abide them kind... an' you will find a lot of them in the saloons... tramps an' drunk teamsters an' crazy miners... sportin' pistols like they was bad men, but not having no sand nor character... not even bad character. ww is really getting wet and he is moving the chair.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on his own wave length) I do not like assassins an' men of low character like your friend English Bob... but Bob ain't no coward who will cry to your face an' then... ww Uh... Sheriff... Uh...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. (looking up sadly) Another one, huh? Shit, I guess I'm clean out of receptacles.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (trying a joke with effort) Maybe you should... hang the carpenter.  67.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (jaw dropping) What?

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (uneasy) Uh... hang the... uh... carpenter. I... There is a sudden loud knocking on the door and Bill turn and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: On a night like this? What the hell? Opening the door he reveals Charlie Hecker, wearing a sli and shedding water like a waterfall.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Three seedy lookin' fellas come inta town, Bill. They're down to Greely's an' at least two of ‘em got guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on the whiskey bottle and Ned is pouring the bright liquid into his glass and Munny is mesmerized by the dazz highlights. The two of them are sitting at a table in Greely's smokey, dimly lit bar room and the rain is beati on the roof and there is a checker game at a table fiftee feet away attended by Germany Joe Schultz, Tom Luckinbill farmer, Eggs Anderson, the local restauranteur and Paddy McGee the cooper. All of them are sneaking occasional, furtive glances at the strangers, as is Fatty who is talk to Skinny at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: ...in hell's takin' The Kid so long? You suppose he... (seeing Munny) Jesus, Bill you look like shit. Munny looks dazed and shakes his head to clear it.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: You... you remember Eagle Hendershot?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (startled) Huh? Uh... yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I seen him.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: He's dead, Bill.  68.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: His head was all busted open so's you could see the inside.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Jesus, Bill, you got fever. Take a drink, will you?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (ignoring Ned) Worms was comin' out.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (getting up) Listen, Bill, I'm gonna see what's takin' The Kid so long. Must be he's gettin' an advance offa them sportin' ladies. Ned starts for the back room, then stops and goes back.

dialogues.speaker: NED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say, Bill... If I was to... take a little while myself... I guess you... I guess you... I guess you don't want to come? Munny shakes his head "no" and, as Ned departs for the Billiard Room, Munny stares vacantly at the whiskey bottl

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: . me your pistol, mister.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (looking up, startled) Huh? The big man in the dripping slicker is standing only ten feet away... Little Bill. And Little Bill is looking at him. Munny can feel everybody in the room staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: I says, "You'll want to give over your pistol." Munny can see Charley moving slowly along the wall on the left for position... and Fatty is over on the right, Skin beside him... and WW is by the door shifting nervously an the checker players are frozen in their seats and Munny c feel them all... watching him.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Uh, no. No, I ain't drunk.  69.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (almost friendly) Ordinance says you got to turn in your firearms to the County office day or night. I guess you didn't read it with the weather an' all.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (nervously) Well... uh... I... I ain't got no, uh, firearms.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (not friendly any more) Them friends of yours in the back, they carryin' pistols?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I... dunno. I mean, I guess not. No, they ain't carryin' no guns.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: You're spillin' your whiskey, mister.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Like I said, I...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Uh, William... uh... Hendershot. Little Sue looks timidly in from the Billiard Room, bites her lip, and retreats quickly.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Well, Mister Hendershot, if I was to call you a no good sonofabitch an' a liar, an' if I was to say you shit in your pants on account of a cowardly soul... well, I guess then, you would show me your pistol right quick an' shoot me dead, ain't that so?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (trapped) I... I guess I might... but like I said, I ain't armed. Little Bill pulls out his pistol and points it at Munny a makes a little motion with the barrel that means "get up" and Munny gets up.  70. Little Bill steps close to him and reaches out with his l hand and opens Munny's coat revealing the Starr tucked in his belt.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: I guess you just carry it for snakes an' such.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Uh... yeah. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (cold) There ain't no snakes in here, Mister Hendershot.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Well, uh... it ain't loaded. Little Bill takes the pistol out of Munny's belt and slow and deliberately ejects five cartridges and he looks at M who is sweating and Munny just wants a way out.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, the powder's wet an... WHACK! Little Bill brings the muzzle of the gun across Munny's temple and blood flows and Munny goes to one knee and Little Bill kicks him hard, WHUMP!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (turning to Ww) Mister Beauchamp, this here is the sort of trash I was speakin' of. Munny is struggling to his feet and staggering weak-kneed the table where he grabs the whiskey bottle and breaks it off and turns groggily to face Little Bill. Little Bill, unperturbed, advances on him and when Munny strikes desperately with the bottle, Little Bill blocks h blow easily and slams him hard with the muzzle of the pis and Munny goes down again.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to ww) You will find these kind in the saloons of your prosperous communities. (WHUMP, he kicks Munny) But you will not find none of them in Big Whiskey. Munny is on the floor on all fours, trying gamely to get  71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned pushing The Kid out the window of Alice's room and Th Kid isn't fully dressed and neither is Ned but he pushes frantically into the rainy night anyway and Alice is urgi them on and Little Sue looks ready to wet her pants.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (to Ned) Hurry. (to Little Sue) You know what to say to Little Bill? Little Sue nods "yes" but she is speechless with terror a Alice hands Ned's boots out the window to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the window, NIGHT, RAIN, and Ned and The Kid tryi to get dressed in the mud and Alice sticks her head out t window.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: You got to look sharp for that old oak. You miss the oak an' you ain't gonna find it.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (to The Kid) Never mind your shirt, get them boots on. Ned is trying to get his own boots on and he goes down on his ass in the mud.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: The roof ain't much but...

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: What about Bill? What we gonna do about...

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Come on, Kid. I hope them horses is still there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny crawling along the floor of the bar room, covered w blood, heading for the door.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Let the man out, WW. He is desiring to leave the hospitality of Big Whiskey behind him.  72. Munny is crawling past WW's legs and WW looks down at the miserable semi-conscious creature and he sees clearly the left hand and the three fingers as they fight for tractio and then WW steps to the door and opens it and Munny craw into the rain and the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAP! Alice gets Little Bill's big hand across the face.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: Easy, Little Bill, she's gotta work she's gotta turn a dollar a time. Little Bill glares at Skinny. They are in Alice's room an Charley is there and Little Sue and WW and it is pretty crowded.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (to Alice) If they was just here for the fuckin', how come they lit out the back window?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (defiant) On account of they seen you was beatin' on their friend.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: (bravely) Th-th-they just c-c-come for the b-b- billiards, Little Bill, honest.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (snorting) Billiards! (to Little Sue) An' they was just passin' through?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: Th-th-they was g-g-goin to F-f-fort B-b-buford t-t-to...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (nasty) You just kicked the shit out of a innocent man, you big asshole.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Innocent of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The south end of town, NIGHT, RAIN and the Albino mare wa aimlessly with Munny slumped in the saddle and then two r come from between two shadowy buildings and it is The Kid and Ned and they come alongside Munny, one on each side o  73. him and Ned lifts his slumped head up and looks at the battered face and winces and says with his eyes what The says with his tongue.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CANDLELIGHT, Ned and The Kid, and Ned is sewing Munny's f with a needle and thread.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Hold him, dammit. It is some sort of straw-filled shed and they have stuck candle on a board.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (sickened) Jesus. (pause) You done this before?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (working) Plenty of times. Munny is only semi-conscious and The Kid is holding his f still.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: His pistol must of jammed.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Move the candle closer, I can't see.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He wouldn't of took no beating like that if it hadn't of jammed. He wouldn't just give it over an' not shoot no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAYLIGHT in the shed and Munny's face, waxy yellow, crude stitching, hideous swelling eyes vacant, breathing heavy. He is lying in the straw and The Kid is looking down at h with distaste. The Kid is only partly dressed.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He don't look so good. The sound of the rain is different: it's still coming but isn't a storm any more.  74. The shed is an irregular shelter because one wall and var parts of the roof have collapsed and the woods outside ar clearly visible. Silky is sitting on some straw straightening her clothes Ned and Alice are climbing out of a corner where they hav obviously been at it and are in various states of dress.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Alice) He didn't even pull his pistol, huh?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (irritated) He ain't as tough as you, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I woulda at least pulled my pistol an...

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Shit, Kid, you pulled your pistol... right outta the lady an' out the back window.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: That was your idea, I wanted to...

dialogues.speaker: SILKY
dialogues.text: (getting up and smoothing herself) We gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Huh? Already? Hey, I'm near ready for another advance.

dialogues.speaker: SILKY
dialogues.text: You're gonna use it all up before you get it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (about to leave) No more advances on what you ain't done yet.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well, we're just waitin' on the weather. If the weather breaks tomorrow we could...

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (to Alice) We're gonna need more food... at least three days worth...  75.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Three days? We could kill 'em tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (a sharp look at The Kid) I don't kill nobody without him. (indicating Munny)

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (frustrated) We don't need him. The two of us could do it. The horses are partly under the roof and Alice and Silky leading theirs out and nobody is paying attention to The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (petulantly) He ain't nothin' but a broken down pig farmer.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (mounting her horse, to Ned) One of us'll bring food in the morning. I guess you'll want some whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: An' medicine if you got it... The Kid walks over to the edge of the broken wall and fro the other corner Munny moans loudly and then screams.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Ohhhhh, ooohhhh no. No, I didn't do nothin'. Ned hurries over to Munny and The Kid is left there with two Whores who are both mounted now and The Kid is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Don't it make you sick, hearin' him like that? (The Whores turn their horses) Don't you ladies worry none...Me an' Ned, we'll kill those two fuckers. And The Kid has picked up two pieces of paper that the wh gave them earlier and they are charcoal sketches, one of Davey Bunting and the other of Quick Mike and they are pr fair likenesses.  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a lantern hanging from a beam in the shed and it night again and the rain has stopped though you can still hear water dripping from the eaves.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: It was a lot of shit what my uncle told me, huh? They are playing cards on the straw floor, Ned and The Ki and Ned doesn't look up from his cards.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Depends what he told you. (pause) About Bill, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: All of it. About him, an' you an' Uncle Pete... about robbin' the Rock Island Pacific... an' about them Missouri Banks.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: We done that stuff.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well I guess Bill Munny wasn't no fearless killer an' bank robber like he said. In the other corner of the room Munny gives a loud moan a both men look at him and then back to their cards.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Kid, it ain't gonna mean nothin' to you, but the roof I built on my house, it don't have a leak in it... not one. (The Kid looks perplexed) Most folks think a school house is the first sign of civilizin'...but I say it's a good roof. Well, that amazes The Kid, being stuck here with these tr robber-bad men and now this shit about roofs and he just stares.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Claudia... No... Oh, Jesus, Claudia, ohh... Ned gets up and takes the lantern over to where Munny is lying and kneels beside him. Munny looks ghastly, at deat door.  77.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Claudia... ain't here, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (reaching) Ned... Is that you, Ned? (holding Ned's arm) Ned, I seen... death.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Easy, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I seen the angel of death Ned, an' I seen the river. (panicked) He's a snake, he got... snake eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Who, Bill? Who got snake eyes?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: The angel... the angel of death. I'm scared, Ned. Ned, I'm gonna die.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Easy, Bill, easy. The Kid has walked over and is watching and it fascinates and scares him and he watches and swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I seen her... I seen Claudia too...

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (soothing) Well, that's good now, ain't it, Bill? Seein' Claudia an...?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: She was all covered with worms. Oh, Ned, I'm scared of dyin'... The Kid can't takes any more and he turns and walks away Ned tries to comfort Munny and Munny grabs him and pulls close.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ned... don't tell nobody... don't tell the kids... don't tell 'em none of... none of the things I done. And Ned has tears in his eyes and Munny's eyes are starin and he is seeing something horrible and we  78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VISION, DAYLIGHT and the horse horribly bloody, screami silently in agony while the sound is the sound of night a the shed and the rain dripping but that doesn't diminish agony of the bloody animal as the whip falls on the head the eyes and we see the YOUNG MAN cruelly wielding the wh It is Munny fifteen years earlier and it is a picture of unbelievable cruelty and viciousness... because that is w he was like and what he remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT in the shed, a little moonlight coming in through t open wall. The lantern is out and the sound is the sound Munny's labored breathing and Ned and The Kid are in thei blankets.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He's gonna die, ain't he?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well, suppose he does?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (after a pause) We'll bury him.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: That ain't what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: You mean, am I gonna help you kill them cowboys?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I can't spot 'em myself but you could. That red-haired one, you could spot a half-mile off, I bet.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: An' if I spot ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I'll ride up close an' shoot ‘em!

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I told you I'm a damn killer. I done it before. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pause, you can hear Munny breathing) I'm more killer than him.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAYLIGHT and the cut-whore's face. Delilah is leaning ove Munny wiping his brow. He is lying in the straw looking u at her and he looks like shit... his face ghastly pale an stubbled and covered with horrible cuts and bad stitching but his eyes are clear.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I thought... you was an angel.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (embarrassed, getting up) You ain't dead. Delilah goes over to her horse and gets some packages out the saddle bags. Munny tries to sit up weakly.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Some big guy beat the shit out of me. (feeling his sore face) I guess I must look a lot like you, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (angry, hurt) You don't look nothin' like me, mister.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I didn't mean no offense. (she doesn't answer) I guess you're the one them cowboys cut up. (no answer) Ned an' The Kid, my partners, are they... ?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (coldly) They went out scouting when they saw your fever broke.  80.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Scouting?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: On the Bar T... looking for... them.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Oh. How long I been here?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (still cold) Three days. Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Three days? I must be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on robins, four of them in the woods near the shed Munny is watching them where he sits wolfing chicken hung his back against the shed. Delilah is watching him eat.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I thought I was gone. See them birds? Most times I wouldn't even notice them birds much. But I'm noticin' "em real good 'cause I thought I was dead.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: I brought your hat. You... left it down at Greely's.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: That big guy lookin' for me? As he looks over at her Munny's eye falls briefly on her exposed ankle and Delilah feels the look.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Little Bill? He thinks you went North. Munny can't help it and his eye flicks back to the ankle.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you really going to kill them?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (unenthusiastically) Yeah, I guess. (suddenly) There's still a payment, ain't there? She nods and she moves so that more ankle is showing, but Munny's eye is drawn to her breasts as she moves, then he  81. looks away quickly, guiltily and they sit there silently until...

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Them other two, they been takin' advances on the payment.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Advances? He can't help looking at her body and she knows it.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (shyly) Free ones. Her body is getting to him.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (stupidly) Free ones?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Alice an' Silky gave them... free ones.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (understanding, embarrassed) Oh. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (shy, timid) You want... a free one.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (looking away, embarrassed) Me? No. No, I guess not. And Delilah is hurt... crushed. She gets up and covers it by picking up the remains of the chicken and Munny is too embarrassed to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (covering her hurt) I didn't mean... with me. Alice and Silky, they'll give you one... if you want.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I... I guess not. (unusually perceptive suddenly) I didn't mean I didn't want one 'cause of you bein' cut up. I didn't mean that.  82. Delilah keeps her back to him.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (trying to get up) It ain't that at all. You're a beautiful woman. What I said before, how I might look like you ... I didn't mean you was ugly like me, hell no... I only meant how we both had scars. He is standing weakly, supporting himself on the wall and his speech is so sincere and Delilah wants to believe it.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a beautiful woman an'... if I was to want a free one, I guess I'd want you more than them others. It ain't... See... I can't have no free one on account of my wife...

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: Your wife?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. See?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I admire that, you being true to your wife. I've seen a lot of... of men... who weren't.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (pleased and embarrassed) Yeah, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: She back in Kansas?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Uh... yeah. Yeah. She's uh... watchin' over the little ones. And Munny gives her what for him is his best social smile sort of like a pig strangling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on the BAWLING CALF and the red hot iron coming out the fire. It is midday in the box canyon and the four cowboys, Texas Slim, Johnny Foley, Lippy Macgregor and Da Bunting are branding strays and Johnny has the calf down ready for the pigging string but the calf kicks loose and knocks Johnny into the fire and the other three cowboys a guffawing, their sweaty faces full of the camaraderie of hardworking men who might get irritable by the end of the  83. day but not yet. And then like a flash, still laughing, young Davey is on his paint and riding like hell after th stray and it is beautiful to watch because he and the pai are like one. CRACK! A rifle shot and the pony does a violent somersaul and Davey goes over in a spray of dirt and fifty yards aw Texas Slim, Lippy and Johnny stare in frozen horror. The downed pony spurts blood from his nostrils, and Davey right leg is pinned under the dying paint's flank and the are maybe fifteen yards from the edge of the canyon and Davey's first thought is the pony.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, fella... (shouting) Boys, my pony's hurt... And turning he sees the three cowboys standing fifty yard away, frozen in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boys... And they suddenly turn and run away toward some rocks and is only then that the terror hits Davey and in a sudden p he tries to get free of the horse.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, boys, my leg's broke. I'm pinned, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on Ned, his face covered with sweat, the Spencer aga his cheek and he is crouched among some boulders up the c wall about three hundred yards from Davey and Munny is lo over Ned's shoulder and The Kid is trying to see, too, squinting desperately, but he can't see shit.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Finish him, Ned.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: He ain't dead? You didn't get him?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (to the Kid, without turning) He got the boy's horse. Looking down the barrel of the rifle Ned can see Davey struggling frantically to get free of the horse and it is easy shot and Ned is sweating, his hand is shaking and he can hear Munny's voice.  84.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Better get him 'fore he gets clear of the horse, Ned. And Ned is shaking and CRACK, he fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on Davey and dust kicking up a foot away and the ext terror gives him the strength to pull free of the horse.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (distant, shouting) Assassin assholes. You dirty asshole sonsabitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny and Ned and The Kid and Ned is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Did you kill him?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: He's clear of the horse, Ned. Better get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on Davey and he is crawling clear of the horse but h leg is broken and it's hard and he looks toward the rocks where his friends are hiding sixty yards away.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS SLIM'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from behind rock) Behind you, Davey. Go for them rocks behind you. And turning, Davey can see a couple of boulders only fift yards away that will provide cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned aiming and shaking.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: What happened? He ain't dead? what's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (to Ned) If he gets behind them rocks we ain't gonna get him... not without we go down there.  85.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: What rocks? Why don't you shoot? What's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fuckin' bushwhackin' assholes. And looking down the barrel Ned can see Davey crawling fo the rocks and it is an easy shot and he can't do it and h looks up at Munny and the agony in his eyes says it all.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Ain't you gonna shoot? Is he dead? Munny grabs the rifle and Ned moves aside and slumps agai a rock and Munny looks down the barrel and aims.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I ain't much of a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey crawling and CRACK! The dust kicks up eight feet aw He is ten yards from the boulders and it is agony to craw

dialogues.speaker: LIPPY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Keep goin', Davey boy. CRACK! Dust puffs up three feet from Davey's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny, the rifle at his cheek and The Kid leaning frantic over his shoulder, trying to see.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: What happened, did you hit him? BANG! BANG! Pistol shots from below and the bullets ping harmlessly among the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're shootin' at us.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We'll kill you, you assholes. Munny is aiming, he can see Davey, nearer shelter now. CRACK! He fires and sees the dust spurt near Davey.

dialogues.speaker: LIPPY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You assholes... you stinking ambushing assholes.  86.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Did you get him? Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey crawling frantically and CRACK!... dust explodes on inches from his head and he is pulling himself franticall and he is only three yards from safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Munny and he is sweating.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: How many shots I got, Ned? Ned is sitting there dazed, staring vacantly. BANG, BANG, BANG, return fire pings off the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (aiming)

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Two. And looking down the rifle Munny can see Davey's head disappear behind the boulder and CRACK, Munny fires again

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Did you get him? BANG BANG BANG the pistol fire.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS SLIM'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Keep goin', Davey. Munny is cocking and aiming for his last shot and he can Davey's legs sticking out from the rock and they're not moving.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Tell me... Christ...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...murderin' bastards...

dialogues.speaker: LIPPY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...fuckin' skunks... CRACK, Munny fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW ON dust puffing as Davey's legs disappear behind the boulder, and there is a low groan.  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on Munnt sitting back against the rock, exhausted, covered with sweat and he holds the rifle up to The Kid.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Better re-load it.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You missed him? You didn't...?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I got him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (scared, hurt) Jesus, boys, I'm shot... they shot me...

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS SLIM'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You tramps... you murderin' tramps.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (shaken) He ain't killed.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (washed out) Maybe, maybe not. Got him in the gut, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey lying behind the boulder and the whole front of him soaking in bright red blood and the sun is beating down.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus... I'm hurt... I'm hurt. They shot me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny sitting there, his back against the rock, staring vacantly and Ned looks the same.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (derisively) Them assholes can't hit us up here. Just wastin' bullets. The cowboys must realize that because they stop shooting you can hear Davey moaning and Ned and Munny just sit the and sweat and The Kid is pacing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think he's gonna die? You think we killed him?  88. Ned and Munny look into each other's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Help me, boys, help me...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (flatly) Yup... we killed him, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, help me boys, I don't want to die... I don't want to die.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (rattled, shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davey is lying there behind the boulder drenched in blood looking up at the blazing noonday sun.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY
dialogues.text: (shouting) I'M DYIN', BOYS. He pauses then, and then he speaks in a normal voice, as though to himself, to express his amazement, to test real

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm dyin'. (pause) I'm dyin'. (shouting, panicked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny sweating and looking up at the sun, and Ned staring vacantly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm thirsty, Slim, Jesus, I'm thirsty. (pause) Bring me a drink won't you, Slim? One drink, Slim... I'm dyin', Slim... (pause) Boys, bring me a drink. it is getting to all three of them and Munny looks up at the sun and then Ned gets up and he walks over to a rock and he vomits.  89.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One drink... please, boys... just one d...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (leaping up, shouting)

dialogues.speaker: ASSHOLES.
dialogues.text: THE BOULDERS. Nothing happens, you can't tell if the cowb are behind there or not.

dialogues.speaker: DAVEY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please boys... I'm shot in the gut... I'm bleedin'... bring me...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: SHOOT.
dialogues.text: There is a pause and Munny looks down at the boulders whe the cowboys are hiding.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS SLIM'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from behind the boulder) You ain't gonna shoot?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: No. And then, after a long moment, Munny sees Texas Slim come out from behind the boulder and run nervously toward the rock where Davey lies and he is carrying a canteen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don't you shoot him, you assholes. The Kid is trying to see but of course he can't.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: They takin' water?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Munny is watching and he sees Texas Slim disappear behind the boulder where Davey is lying and there is a moment of silence... and then the voice, a scream of grief and anguish...  90.

dialogues.speaker: TEXAS SLIM'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (from behind the boulder) Oh, Jesus, Johnny, they've killed him... they've shot up his gut... oh Jesus, they've killed young Davey... oh, those murderin' bastards, they've killed our Davey... And The Kid spits in the dust and Ned wipes his forehead with his bandanna and Munny scuffs the dirt with his boot

dialogues.speaker: HOOVES ON
dialogues.text: FLAT ROCK and the three riders, Munny, Ned and The Kid, are trotting their horses over a smooth slab of rock near a hill. They are silent, glum, then,

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: When we gonna double back?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: After a ways.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (not looking at them) Not me. Munny looks up sharply but Ned just looks straight ahead. Ned reins Kid.

dialogues.speaker: NED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm goin' on down to Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: We got to kill this other one first. (Ned doesn't answer) Shit, Ned, if we're lucky, we could kill him by nightfall... or maybe tomorrow morning. Then we could head back, all three of us, with the money. in his horse and Munny pulls up too and then The

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (looking him in the eye) You want the Spencer, Bill? (he holds out the rifle)

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (lamely) Shit, Ned, this ain't the time to quit.  91.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You're gonna lose your share. If you don't...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Shut up, Kid. Ned just holds out the rifle and after a moment Munny tak it and Ned takes a box of cartridges from his pocket and hands them over.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: I'll see you, Bill. See you, Kid. And he turns his horse and heads off across open country a trot and Munny watches him go till he's about fifty yar away.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (shouting) HOLD ON, NED. And Ned reins up and Munny gallops up to him and holds ou the Spencer and the bullets.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain't worth a shit with it. Ned takes the rifle, sheathes it, gives a curt nod and tu to go.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me an' the Kid, we'll head over to the ranch an' as soon as we find him, we'll shoot him. Then we'll come back an' the three of us pick up the money an' head South together.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Supposin' he don't go to the ranch?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I'll bet anything he won't go to town nor he won't ride out on the range. Right off he'll hole up at the ranch.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: (turning away) I ain't waitin', Bill. (looking back) I'll look in on your youngsters when I get back.  92.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (calling after him) Ned, don't pay no mind to what the Kid said about the money. I'll bring your share along, hear? The Kid's full of shit, hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on the roof, late afternoon, and Little Bill is craw around up there with a bucket of tar which he has got on moustache and his face and he looks up because he hears t clatter of hooves.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON CHARLEY HECKLER
dialogues.text: Galloping his horse up to Little Bill's house and Charley very excited and he swings off the horse in front of the porch and the porch is at once closer to completion and c to collapse than last we saw it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (looking around, breathless) Little Bill, Little Bill...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Charley looks up, startled and Little Bill is looking dow at him over the eaves.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (sheepish) Makin' some repairs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: (breathless) The killed one of them cowboys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NIGHT, CLOSE VIEW on torchlight flickering on Davey's wax face and dead eyes as Eggs, Germany Joe and Paddy haul th blood-caked body from the back of a buckboard. WW is look on queasily, taking notes, and behind him the street is a

dialogues.speaker: WIGGENS' VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...an' Parsons said how he seen three men right after sun-up headed out East an' one was ridin' a old blue Morgan an' another was on a white mare, only he didn't... And only a few yards away from the buckboard, in front of the County Office, Little Bill is being besieged by Deput and Townsmen.  93.

dialogues.speaker: FATTY
dialogues.text: Amos over at the stable says to ask you if the County's payin' feed for ALL the horses or if...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: ...Witherspoon says he ain't gonna sell us no more thirty-thirty shells without we pay... And the dogs, snarling, fangs bared, pulling at the leash and Tom Luckinbill is trying to keep control.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: ...use the dogs then the county's gotta take responsibility for...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (calmly) Never mind about them horses, Fatty. Just you ride out to the Bar T an' make sure that other cowboy stays put an' don't expose himself, hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice's room and the whores. They are sitting glumly in t dim light of a simple lamp. Little Sue is wiping tears aw and Delilah is staring blankly.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (to no one in particular) I didn't think they'd really do it.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (nasty) What did you think, they come clear up from Kansas to fuck us?

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (vacantly) That Kid... he's just a... boy. And that other one, Bill, being true to his wife...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: What wife? He don't have no wife.

dialogues.speaker: DELILAH
dialogues.text: (shocked, hurt) He said...

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: I told you, he don't have no wife, not aboveground, anyhow.  94. Delilah just eats the pain raw and just then... SMASH! A rock comes through the window and you can hear someone shouting.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE OUTSIDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You fuckin' murderin' whores. And they all sit there stunned and then Alice recovers an gets up and goes to the window and hurls the rock back.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Bill and the crowd and the torches outside the Cou Office and suddenly there is a commotion and shouting and everybody turns North and... Fuzzy is riding into town at full gallop shouting at the of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: FUZZY
dialogues.text: We got one. We got one of them fuckers, we got one... Bystanders part as Fuzzy brings the horse up in front of County Office and reins hard and addresses himself breathlessly to Little Bill.

dialogues.speaker: FUZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We got one of them fuckers, Sheriff, out by Cow Creek, we...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Alive?

dialogues.speaker: FUZZY
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah. A bunch of us Bar T boys went out lookin' on account of them killin' one of our own. We come across this fucker on a roan goin' South an'...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: He admit it?

dialogues.speaker: FUZZY
dialogues.text: No... but I guess he will soon enough. Had a Spencer rifle on him an' he was...  95.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Those cowboys messin' him up?

dialogues.speaker: FUZZY
dialogues.text: Uh... a little, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (to Clyde) You an' Andy get the hell out there. Find out where them other two went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAWN, the outhouse, birds chirping cheerily and the outho door opens and BUCK BARTHOL steps out and stretches luxuriously. VIEW on bushes and The Kid holding his nose. The bushes a right behind the outhouse and the stink is terrible. The Kid is crouched there and he is doing an elaborate pantom of his suffering for Munny's benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on Buck coming into the bunkhouse. There isn't much light and the shadowy sleeping figures are more easily discernable by the snorts and snores they make than by th shapes... except for THIRSTY and Quick Mike who are sitti half dressed at a table rolling cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: THIRSTY
dialogues.text: See anythin' out there, Buck?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Hell, yes I did. (Mike looks up nervously) Seen about two hundred fellers packin' rifles... Fuckers got the place surrounded, says they want Quick Mike's ass... I says, "How much?" They says, "About five." I says, "Dollars?" They says, "Cents." I says, "Sold."

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Well I ain't worried I got protection. (he indicates a nearby bunk) Fatty snoring on the bunk near Quick Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Ned's face, nose bloodied, eye blackened, as he rides down the Main Street of Big Whiskey escorted by six cowboys (including Texas Slim, Johnny Foley and Lippy  96. MacGregor) and Clyde and Andy. Ned's wrists are tied and looks sullen and... scared. Little Bill and WW Beauchamp are standing on the porch of the County Office when the little group pulls up attended numerous onlookers. Little Bill looks Ned over coolly as addresses Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: He tell you where them others is?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: He give 'em names?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Didn't give us nothin' but his own name... Ned Roundtree.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Well, Ned, you'll want to tell me an' Mister Beauchamp here all about them two villainous friends of yours, I guess. (to Clyde and Andy) Bring him in, boys, for I will be glad to know the names and the whereabouts of those other two murdering sonsofbitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on the mid day sun blazing from on high and an enorm farting sound...

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE OUTHOUSE
dialogues.text: After a pause, another vigorous fart and then silence bro only by the buzzing of flies, and then the sound of newsp and suddenly the door opens and Thirsty steps out and hea up toward the bunkhouse.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE KID
dialogues.text: In the bushes reacting to the smell and the flies are buz furiously.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Sure is fuckin' ripe. I wish we'd get a breeze. Munny wipes sweat from his face and looks up at the blazi sun.  97.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: It's gonna get riper yet.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You still think he's in there?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (his eyes on the bunkhouse) Yeah, he's in there.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Well, he's holding on to his shit like it was money.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: He's in there.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Tell me right off if you see him.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You... you ain't gonna shoot him yourownself?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (tired of saying it) You can shoot him. The Kid nods, satisfied, but he's keyed up something fero and his fingers play nervously with his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Ned's face jammed against the bars of the cell i the County Office. He has been tied to the bars outside t cell so that he is, more or less, spread-eagled in an upr position with his bare back exposed to Little Bill and Ch Hecker and WW Beauchamp.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Now then, Ned... you an'... uh... Mister Quincy an' uh... What was that young feller's name?

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Tate. Elroy Tate. ww shakes his head at Little Bill and holds out his noteb for Little Bill to see.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: That ain't what you said before, Ned.  98. Little Bill empties hot coals from the bowl of his pipe o Ned's shoulders and Ned writhes and grots his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Hellif it ain't.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (looking at W's notes) Before you said Elroy Quincy out of Medicine Hat an' Henry Tate out of Cheyenne.

dialogues.speaker: NED
dialogues.text: Fuck if I did.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (refilling his pipe) Charley, go bring them whores here that fucked these boys the night of the storm.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Strawberry Alice an' Silky?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Yeah... an' fetch a bullwhip out of the German's. Ned's face against the bars is covered with perspiration etched with fear as he hears the door close behind Charle

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (lighting his pipe) Now, Ned... them whores are gonna lie different lies than you... an' when your lie ain't the same as their lie... I ain't gonna hurt no woman, I'm gonna hurt you... not gentle like I been doin' but... baaaad. Ned swallows hard and sweats and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on cards. They are playing at the little table in t bunkhouse, Quick Mike, Buck, Thirsty, Fatty Rossiter and OLAF HARKEN and Quick Mike doesn't even have a pair and t his cards down in disgust and walks over to his bunk and starts to put on his boots.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: (to Mike) Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: QUICK MIKE
dialogues.text: Take a shit.  99.

dialogues.speaker: FATTY
dialogues.text: (he has two kings) Lemmee finish this hand, will you?

dialogues.speaker: QUICK MIKE
dialogues.text: You gonna protect me while I take a shit? Quick Mike walks over to a peg and hangs a gunbelt over h bare shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: You could get bushwhacked.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK MIKE
dialogues.text: (heading for the door) I'll fart on ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: THIRSTY
dialogues.text: (starting to get up) I'll go with him.

dialogues.speaker: QUICK MIKE
dialogues.text: You could wipe my ass, Thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: THIRSTY
dialogues.text: (sitting down) Hell with him. Man ain't polite, he oughta get shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid in the bushes and he hears the door slamming shut at the bunkhouse and he squints anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (whispering) Is it him?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (watching Mike) Yup. The Kid is beside himself, his throat goes dry and he gul for air and he brings the hammer back on his pistol and squints anxiusly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gradually Mike comes into focus walking closer and we

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE KID
dialogues.text: Sweating, tensed for action and Munny looks over at him.  100.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering) He's yours, Kid. Can you get him? And The Kid is biting his lip and doesn't answer and Quic Mike is very close and The Kid brings up his pistol and g and doesn't shoot and then it is too late because Mike ha entered the outhouse. Munny is disgusted and he cocks the shotgun to do it hims The Kid is walking on eggshells approaching the door of t outhouse, pistol in his right hand and he reaches his lef hand to open the door but he is hesitant and... Munny sees Fatty Rossiter step casually out of the bunkho and Munny raises the shotgun and Fatty sees The Kid and screams.

dialogues.speaker: ASSASSINS, BOYS, ASSASSINS
dialogues.text: BAWHOOM! Munny lets go with the shotgun and Fatty dives back into the bunkhouse and... The Kid is startled and looks over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOT HIM, KID
dialogues.text: and The Kid grabs the door with his left hand and opens i and there is Mike sitting on the crapper astonished and o hand is on his holstered pistol but he's frozen and The K is pointing the Schofield at him but The Kid is frozen to

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: BLAM! The Schofield jumps in The Kid's hand and Mike gets it in the chest and there is smoke all over and The Kid s at Mike amazed and Mike who has a big splotch of blood on his chest stares back at The Kid amazed also and then... BLAM, The Kid shoots him again, this time in the face. BANG! BANG! shots from the bunkhouse and... BAWHOOM! Munny blasts the bunkhouse with shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Come on, Kid. BLAM, The Kid shoots Mike's slumping body a third time an he seems hypnotized but... BANG BANG shots are coming from the bunkhouse and Munny i screaming and The Kid tears himself away.  101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny crashing through the bushes and The Kid is a few ya behind him and Munny stumbles and scrambles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Did... you... get... him?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (amazed) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The outhouse and Mike's body and Fatty and Thirsty and Bu dashing past, waving their guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The albino mare and the Morgan in the woods and Munny and The Kid dash up to the horses, gasping for breath, and Mu tries to mount still holding the shotgun and the horse st to prance around and Munny can't mount.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Hold still. BANG, BANG, BANG shots are whistling around them and look back Munny can see his pursuers firing from cover fifty y away. Munny shoves two shells in the shotgun and hands it to Th Kid who has mounted.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cover me, Kid, while I mount.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (panicked) I can't see 'em.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Just SHOOT! And KA BLAMMM, The Kid lets go both barrels in the genera direction of the enemy and then Munny gallops away half o his horse, half-off, in an undignified escape, bullets whistling around his horse and The Kid behind him shoutin

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Where are you, Bill, where are you, I can't see you. Wait for me. and then they disappear and gradually the shooting atops.  102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open country at sundown seen from a low hill, and you can barely make out a lone RIDER approaching in the extreme distance.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MUNNY
dialogues.text: Standing on the rise and watching the rider in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Is that what it was like, Bill, in the old days... ridin' out with everybody shootin'... smoke all over an' folks yellin' an' bullets whizzin' by? The Kis is behind Bill sitting under a large oak drinking from a whiskey bottle.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (absently) Yeah, I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Shit... I thought they was gonna get us. I was even... scared a little... just for a minute. (pause) Was you ever scared in them days? Munny turns from watching the rider's slow approach and w over to The Kid who can't see the rider from where he's sitting.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I don't remember, Kid. I was drunk most of the time. Give me a pull on that bottle, will you? Munny takes a big pull on the bottle, returns it to The K and walks back to the edge of the rise to resume his vigi The rider is a little closer now and the sun is a little lower. It is very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (drinking heavy) I shot that fucker three times. He was takin' a shit. He went for his pistol an' I blazed away... first shot got him in the chest... The Kid wipes whiskey from his chin. He has been working hard to make the hysteria he feels into a high... but it won't quite come.  103.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say, Bill...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Munny is watching the rider and the rider is closer.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: That was... the first one.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: First one what?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: First one I ever killed.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (preoccupied with his vigil) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: How I said I shot five men... it wasn't true. (long pause) That Mexican... the one that come at me with a knife... I busted his leg with a shovel... I didn't shoot him or nothin'. Munny is watching the rider and the rider is much closer coming at a walk and Munny goes back over to The Kid for pull on the bottle and he's trying to make The Kid feel o when he says...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Well, that fella today, you shot him alright.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (forced bravado) H-hell yeah. I killed the hell out of him... three shots... he was takin' a sh-sh-shit an'... an'... The Kid is shaking, becoming hysterical, he can't go on, Munny hands the bottle back.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Take a drink, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (breaking down, crying) Oh Ch-ch-christ... it don't... it don't seem... real... How he's... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: DEAD... how he ain't gonna breathe no more... n-n-never. Or the other one neither... On account of... of just... pullin' a trigger. Munny walks back to the edge of the rise and watches the rider and it is a lovely sunset happening and he is talki to no one in particular.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: It's a hell of a thing, ain't it, killin' a man. You take everythin' he's got... an' everythin' he's ever gonna have...

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (trying to pull himself together) Well, I gu-guess they had it... comin'.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: We all got it comin', Kid. VIEW on the rider at the foot of the rise and it is Littl Sue and VIEW on Munny pulling the saddle bags off and Lit Sue is still mounted. They are under the oak tree and it dusk and The Kid is just sitting there with his bottle.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was watchin' you... seein' if you was followed.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: (scared to death) Silky an' Faith, they rode off to the East an' two deputies was followin' them. Munny has lit a little candle and spread a blanket and he opening the bags to count the money.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (pouring out the coins and bills) You wanna help me count, Kid? The Kid is leaning against the tree in a semi-stupor.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I trust you, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Well, you don't wanna trust me too much. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll take Ned his share together so you don't figure I run off with it.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: (startled) Ned's share?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (counting) Yeah, he went South ahead of us. I guess we'll catch him before...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: (blurting it out) He's... he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (counting) No he ain't. He went South yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: They... they killed him. I... thought you know that. I thought you knew because...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (looking up) Nobody didn't kill Ned, he went South yesterday. He didn't even kill nobody. Why would anybody kill Ned? Little Sue just looks back at him, scared, trembling.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (realizing) Who killed him?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: Little Bill. The... the Bar T boys caught him and Little Bill...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: He hanged him? (Little Sue shakes her head "no") Shot him down?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: N-no. He... he beat him up. He was making him... answer questions... and beating him up... and then... Ned just died. (pause) Little Bill didn't mean to kill him... he said he was sorry an' all... but he said it was a good example anyhow.  106.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (outraged) Good example! Good example of what I'd like to know? He didn't even kill nobody... he couldn't do it no more.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: They got... a sign on him says he was a killer.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (flabbergasted) A sign on him?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: In front of Greely's. It says, "This here is what happens to..."

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (incredulous) They got a sign on him in front of Greely's? The Kid just has his head in his hands, it's too much for him and Little Sue is scared shitless of Munny.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The questions Little Bill asked him... what sort of questions was they?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: About where you an' him (indicating The Kid) was... an' where you was from... an' what your names was... an'...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
