dialogues.text: What'd Ned say?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: L-lies... at first. About how you was just passin' through and didn't kill nobody... an' Little Bill kept askin' questions, mixin' him up, catchin' lies... an' then he'd beat on Ned an' Ned would cry and lie some more an' then... then...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Then... what?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: A cowboy come in sayin' you killed Quick Mike in the shit house at the Bar T...  107.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: An' Little Bill killed Ned for what I done?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: Not on purpose. But he started hurtin' him worse... makin' him tell stuff. First ned wouldn't say nothin'... but Little Bill hurt him so bad he said who you was... Munny looks up sharply. Little Sue is scared, her voice quavers...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He said how you was really Three Fingered Jack out of Missouri... an' Bill said "Same Three Fingered Jack that dynamited the Rock Island and Pacific in '69 killin' women and children an' all?" An' Ned says you done a lot worse than that, said you was more cold blooded than William Bonney or Clay Alisson or the James Brothers an' how if he hurt Ned again you was gonna come an' kill him like you killed a U.S. Marshall in '73.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Didn't scare Little Bill though, did it?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SUE
dialogues.text: N-no, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Lemmee see that Schofield, Kid.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Wha... what f-for?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (sharply) Lemmee see it.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: (giving it to him) Sure. Sure, Bill. Munny takes the pistol and begins to check it methodicall inspecting the load first... and The Kid watches nervousl shifting from foot to foot.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You... you could keep it, Bill. I ain't... gonna use it no more, I ain't gonna kill nobody.  108. Munny, still checking the gun, glances up and meets The K uneasy gaze.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I... I ain't like you, Bill. Munny looks back at the pistol, checks the sights.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You... gonna take... the money?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (to Little Sue) You better get on back, Miss. And Little Sue, still mounted, breathes an enormous silen sigh of relief and turns her horse away hastily and Munny satisfied with the pistol, sticks it in his belt and walk over to the horse and pulls his sawed-off shotgun out of bedroll.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You could have it. All of it.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted to buy spectacles an' fancy clothes an' all.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: I'd rather be blind and ragged than dead, I guess. Munny looks at The Kid who is behaving bravely but is trembling anyway, scared, and Munny's eyes are full of brutally painful memories.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Shit, Kid. I ain't gonna kill you. You're... the only friend I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOONLIGHT on the ordinance #14 sign on the North Road and two riders come up slow, Munny and The Kid, and Munny rei up and then The Kid does too. Munny takes the saddle bags off his horse.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (giving The Kid the bags) This here money, take my share an' Ned's an' leave it with my youngsters. Tell 'em half goes to Sally Two Trees if I ain't back in a week. The rest is yours... you could buy them spectacles.  109.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: Are you... Are you gonna... kill Little Bill?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (holding up the whiskey bottle) I guess you won't mind my keepin' the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: THE KID
dialogues.text: You're gonna kill him, ain't you?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Stay clear of folks you might see. There's plenty out lookin' to hang you. Go on now, skedaddle. Munny slaps The Kid's horse and The Kid sets out at a tro and Munny watches him disappear into the night. When he i alone and he can't hear The Kid's horse any more, Munny uncorks the bottle and takes a long deep drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on Ned's body in the upright coffin in the flickerin light of a torch standing next to it and, of course, Ned looks bad and the crudely scrawled sign over the coffin s "This is what happens to assassins around here."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW on Little Bill in the crowded bar and he is shouting make himself heard over the din.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Alright, I'm gonna say just one more time so it's all clear an' then don't ask me no more. The place is packed with tired, dusty men and they are no really jubilant so much as they are excited by the hyster of events.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now each of you that posse'd today has got one drink comin' off the county budget...

dialogues.speaker: THIRSTY
dialogues.text: Yahoo.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: ...an' whoever rode yesterday, gets one drink for that...  110.

dialogues.speaker: PADDY
dialogues.text: Yippee.

dialogues.speaker: EGGS
dialogues.text: I told yuh two, I...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Hold it hold it. After them two, it's outta your own pocket... hear me, Skinny? ...an' we're pullin' out early tomorrow an' chase these fellas clear to Texas so I wouldn't spend much of your own money. There is a general whoop and hubbub as Little Bill turns back to his conversation at the bar with Charley, Fatty, Clyde, Andy and WW Beauchamp.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now if we divide up into four parties an' hit all the farms an' trails in a circle, we're bound to find some one who seen them skunks an'... Little Bill is suddenly conscious of his own loud voice i sudden silence that has swept the bar like a brushfire an turning he sees what everybody is staring at. Munny, with his ten-gauge shotgun leveled from the should is standing thirty feet away in the doorway. Taking a cou of sideways steps to get the door from behind his back an sweeping the twin barrels in an ominous arc, he surveys t scene.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (a little drunk) Which fucker owns this shithole? Nobosy says a thing. Skinny stares pop-eyed from behind t bar and the sweat starts on his forehead and Little Bill thinking coolly and everybody else is swallowing hard and looking at the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Fatty) You there, fat man, speak up. Fatty gulps and then Skinny screws up his courage and ste from behind the bar and gives it every bit of dignity his fear will permit.

dialogues.speaker: SKINNY
dialogues.text: I... I own this establishment. I bought it from Greely for a thous...  111.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (to the men round Skinny) Better step clear, boys. And Skinny looks from side to side as people step away fr him and he wants to say something desperately, he wants t live, he wants...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: Hold on, mist... BAH-WHOOM! Munny fires and smoke belches and... Skinny is blown back against the wall and falls to the fl a bloody mess and... Little Bill is reaching for the Spencer which is leaning against the bar near his leg but he freezes because... Munny has turned the shotgun on him and Munny sees Ned's Spencer there and his eyes show how he feels about it. For a moment while the smoke clears the bar is silent and there are nervous glances cast at the bloody body of Skin but Little Bill keeps his eyes on Munny.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well sir... You are a cowardly sonofabitch because you have just shot down an unarmed man. It has become a very formal moment and there are, figurat speaking, only two people in the room, Munny and Little Bill... and WW Beauchamp is watching them, scared to deat but this is it, what all those Easterners dreamed about, showdown in the saloon.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (the shotgun pointed right at Little Bill) He should have armed himself if he was gonna decorate his saloon with the body of my friend.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: I guess you are Three-Fingered Jack out of Missouri, killer of women and children.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (a little drunkenly) I have done that... killed women and children... I have killed most everything that walks or crawls an' (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: now I have come to kill you, Little Bill, for what you done to Ned. (to the others) Now step aside. boys. And as the deputies nervously move aside Little Bill help to isolate himself by stepping forward boldly.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: He's got one barrel left, gentlemen. After he has used it, pull your pistols and shoot him down like the cowardly, drunken scoundrel he is. Little Bill looks back at Munny bravely and... Munny looks down the barrel at Little Bill and after a te moment he pulls the trigger. CLICK. The hammer falls but it is a misfire and what happ next happens in maybe five seconds as all hell breaks loo

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (drawing) Misfire! Kill the sonofabitch! And Little Bill aims carefully and... Munny hurls the shotgun at him and... BLAM!... Little Bill fires wildly as the shotgun hits him and... Clyde has his pistol out and is pointing it at Munny and. Munny is pulling the pistol from his own belt and he drop to one knee and... BLAM!... Clyde fires and misses and... Little Bill is about to squeeze the trigger when... BLAM!... Munny shoots him and... BLAM!... Little Bill shoots just as he is hit in the ches and... BLAM! BLAM!... Fatty fires wildly and... Munny is aiming too and BLAM!... Clyde gets it in the face and... BLAM!... BLAM!... Fatty isn't even aiming while... Andy aims carefully, he can kill Munny but...  113. Munny turns and points his weapon at Andy and... Instead of firing Andy panics and tries to turn his body sideways to ward off the blow and... BLAM!... Munny fires and... Andy gets it high in the rib cage and... Charley turns and runs for the back and... BLAM! BLAM!... Fatty is backing up and firing from the hi and then he turns to run and... Munny aims deliberately from one knee and BLAM!... Fatty goes down, shot in the back... And suddenly... there is a terrible silence that is broke only by the awful, dying groans of Clyde and the coughing the bystanders hiding behind tables and chairs in the thi black smoke and... Munny is still down on one knee pointing his pistol and looking through the thick smoke for someone to shoot but seems there are no threats left.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Every asshole that doesn't want to get shot best clear out the back quick. And they scramble over each other dashing toward the Bill Room and Munny stands up and looks around and he looks at Clyde who is groaning, his face covered with blood and everyone else, Little Bill, Andy and Fatty are still, and then Fatty seems to move and Munny levels his pistol and what happens is W crawls out from half-under Fatty and Ww is covered with blood and he is shaking like a leaf.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: I... I... think I'm... shot.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: You ain't shot.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (seeing the pistol) P-p-p-please, I'm not armed. (as Munny lowers the pistol, WW looks around) M-m-my G-god. You killed... Little Bill.  114.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (suspicious) You sure you ain't armed?

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: I never c-c-carry arms. I'm... a writer.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: A writer? What do you write... letters an' such?

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: B-b-books. (amazed) You... you killed five men... singlehanded.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (wearily) Yeah. Munny walks over to the bar, keeping his eye suspiciously Ww, and reaches for a bottle with his left hand. The hand is shaking like palsy and he tilts the bottle and drinks sloppily with effort, the pistol still in his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: Wh-wh-who did you kill first?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: (reciting) Wh-wh-when confronted by superior numbers, the experienced gunfighter will fire on the best shots first.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (drinking) Yeah? Unnoticed on the floor, Little Bill is conscious though b is coming out of his mouth and he has been written off. O hand is shifting on his pistol and he can hear Clyde moan sporadically.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: Little Bill told me that. You killed him first, didn't you? On the floor, Little Bill is fighting for consciousness, fingering his pistol.  115.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I was lucky in the order. (bitterly) I always been lucky killin' folks.

dialogues.speaker: WW
dialogues.text: Who was next? Clyde? Or was it...?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (suddely ominous, pistol pointing) I could tell you who was last, mister. WW's eyes pop as he gets the idea and he backs up fast, a then he turns and bolts out the back, and watching him go Munny turns his back on the fallen body of Little Bill. Little Bill, on the floor, raises up his pistol in his sh hand and aims at Munny's back maybe six feet away and he shaking bad as he draws the hammer back and... Munny hears the click and he turns and sees Little Bill a but it is too late and... BLAM! Smoke and fire from Little Bill's pistol and Little Bill's arm collapses from the effort and the pistol falls with a bang.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Missed again, asshole. And Munny steps over to him and kicks the pistol away fro Little Bill's outstretched hand. Little Bill is bleeding from the mouth having taken a shot in the lung and he is very weak and all he can do is look up at Munny and speak weakly.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: I don't... deserve this... to die this way. I was... building a house.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (aiming his pistol point blank) "Deserve" don't mean shit, Little Bill.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BILL
dialogues.text: (the pistol in his face) I'll see you... in hell, you three- fingered asshole. BLAM! Munny shoots Little Bill and then he looks around a Clyde is still groaning and that is the only sound. Then, suddenly, he is all business. He walks quickly over to Cl and shoots him once with the Spencer and the groaning sto  116. Then he goes to Little Bill's body and pokes around in th pockets and pulls out some shells for the Spencer. He shoves those in his pocket and he goes to the bar and picks up the bottle of whiskey and walks over to the door Standing to one side, he kicks it open. Then he sets down the rifle and the bottle and starts to reload the Schofie and while he loads it he shouts out the door.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I'm comin' outta here... an' any fucker I see out there, I'm gonna kill him... an' any fucker takes a shot at me, I ain't just gonna kill him, but I'm gonna kill his wife an' all his friends an' burn his fucking house, hear? The pistol is loaded and Munny sticks it in his belt and takes a long pull on the whiskey bottle and wipes the dri from his chin. Then he picks up the rifle in the other ha and looks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street and it is dark and quiet, shadowy buildings, t knot of tethered horses, a couple of torches stuck in the ground sputtering.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nobody better shoot on account of I'm as mean as I say... maybe meaner. I am a damn badman an' you will not find a worse one in hell. And Munny steps out the door warily, and looks around and all he sees are the shadowy buildings and all he hears ar his own boots on the wooden porch. Glancing nervously at the dark buildings' blank stares he walks past the uprigh coffin where the waxy face of Ned stares gruesomely in th light of the flickering torch and he gives it a glance, wanting to say he's sorry, but the idea is ludicrous and steps off the porch and walks toward the white mare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WW Beauchamp and Charley Hecker and Germany Joe crouched the alleyway between two buildings across the street and Charley has a rifle and they can see Munny mounting his h

dialogues.speaker: GERMANY JOE
dialogues.text: (whispering) Go ahead, shoot him. Charley just shakes his head and offers the rifle to Germ Joe. And Germany Joe doesn't want it.  117.

dialogues.speaker: GERMANY JOE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I endt no dehpoody. Www is watching Munny's unbelievably awkward and prolonge mounting procedure and he can't believe it, he can't beli what the Old West is like and it shows on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Munny riding down the dark, lonely street at a trot and h starts to shout at the top of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: You boys better bury old Ned right... and you better not carve up nor otherwise harm no whores... or I will come back an' kill more sonsabitches, hear? And there are tears running down Munny's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAYLIGHT and Penny sweeping in the doorway of Munny's sod hut in Kansas. She is intent on her work until she hears the snort of a horse and looks up and her jaw drops, and face lights up like the sun itself and, dropping the broo she dashes toward him.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MUNNY
dialogues.text: Munny walking across the field, leading the mare. He is covered with dust and heavily stubbled from the trip. Penny dashes up to him and throws her arms around him and he is overjoyed but he doesn't have any way to express it except through awkwardness and embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (fondly) Ain't you a lady! And he puts his arm around her and they walk toward the h

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON WILL
dialogues.text: Working in the hog pens in back, concentrating on the job.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Place looks good. And Will whirls around and sees Munny standing there besi the house and his first instinct is to run to him and the  118. he remembers his dignity and stands there like a man, but the grin is liable to break his face.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Hullo, paw.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: I guess you lost some hogs to the fever.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Three.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Three? That ain't bad considerin'. Will is pissing in his pants with pride and pleasure and joins his father and they walk around the house together.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: That fella come by... Tom.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (stopping) Tom?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: The one you rode out after... the one that had the pistol...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: The Kid, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: Only he wasn't carryin' no pistol this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will and Munny in te shed and Will is digging deep into a huge pile of straw.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (worried) He say anythin'... The Kid... ?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (digging) ; ; Tom? Only how... how if you didn't... didn't come back in a week... (upset) how we was to take half the money to Sally an' say you was...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (gently) Well, I come back, didn't I?  119. And Will has exposed the saddle bags and Munny moves in a opens them and gold coins and wads of bills spill out.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (upset) Did you... did you... ?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (counting) Did I what?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: All that money... I mean... did you...?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (counting) Steal it? Naw, I didn't steal it.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: No... I meant...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (turning) What?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: K-k-kill somebody?

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: N-nobody... only you took your shotgun an' that pistol an'...

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (bothered, putting his arm around Will's shoulders) Before I met your maw, God rest her soul, it used to be I was kinda... wicked... drinkin' spirits an' gettin' into scrapes an' all. Only she made me see the error of my ways an'... I ain't like I was no more.

dialogues.speaker: WILL
dialogues.text: (relieved) I guess you didn't kill nobody then.

dialogues.speaker: MUNNY
dialogues.text: (it is an effort) Naw, son, I didn't kill nobody.  120.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grave of Claudia under the trees and Munny walks up t it and maybe we hear music or maybe just the wind, but th words begin to crawl across the screen, supered.

dialogues.speaker: WRITTEN WORDS
dialogues.text: They were married in St. Louis in 1B70 and they traveled North to Kansas where he engaged in farming and swine husbandry. She bore him two children in the eight years of their marriage and when she died, it was not at his hands as her mother might have expected, but of smallpox.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON MUNNY
dialogues.text: We are looking at him by now and there is nothing easy on his face, no big emotions, he is just looking at the grav

dialogues.speaker: WRITTEN WORDS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some years later, Mrs. Ansonia Feathers made the arduous journey to Hodgeman County to visit the last resting place of her only daughter.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON THE GRAVE
dialogues.text: We are looking at the stone now and the words continue.

dialogues.speaker: WRITTEN WORDS
dialogues.text: William Munny had long since sold the place and disappeared with the children... some said to San Francisco where it was rumored he prospered as a dry goods merchant under a different name.

dialogues.speaker: THE EYES OF WILLIAM MUNNY
dialogues.text: The eyes of the husband and the pig-farmer and the man wh shot down five men in the Big Whiskey saloon.

dialogues.speaker: WRITTEN WORDS
dialogues.text: And there was nothing on the stone to explain to Mrs. Feathers why her only daughter had married a known thief and murderer, a man of notoriously vicious and intemperate disposition.
